Even as Boris Johnson urges people to take staycations in the UK, new analysis shows regions which rely on tourism are being disproportionately hit by the rise in unemployment following the coronavirus pandemic.In areas where over a fth of workers are in tourism-related jobs, the number of working-age adults claiming unemployment-related benefits has risen by % since February - compared to % for the UK as a whole.Labour leader Keir Starmer has called for an extension of the Governmentaposs furlough scheme for the worst-hit sectors, including domestic tourism.Ahead of a visit to Falmouth in Cornwall, Sir Keir warned the UK’s world-class destinations are “falling through the cracks” as the Government prepares to wind down the scheme. Some % of workers in Falmouth are in tourism related jobs - and the claimant count has risen by % since February. He said: We are lucky to have many world-class tourist destinations across the UK. “But the jobs crisis facing tourist towns is stark. There are fantastic domestic options for British holidaymakers, but the crucial summer season has been cut short. “With many businesses still unable to reopen fully, the Government’s one-size-fits-all approach to jobs risks these towns falling through the cracks. “We need a targeted extension of the furlough scheme for the hardest-hit sectors and proper support in place to help those who are unemployed back into work.“  In May, the Mirror revealed the ten towns working in lockdown-hit industries had an average monthly pay packet nearly £ lighter than the UK average before the crisis. story: NewsWhen does shielding end  Advice on how to keep yourself safe in new changesThe Governments shielding guidances comes to an end on July , with big changes to daily le for . million people told to stay indoors to protect them from the virusShareCommentsByLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsMatt Hancock said shielding guidance would be lted in August " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMillions of clinically vulnerable people in England will no longer have to follow strict shielding guidance from August under major changes to the rules. In March, the Government ordered . million people with serious health conditions to stay indoors to protect them from coronavirus. The restrictions have been slowly eased, with shielded people allowed to meet up with up to five people from July . And from August  the shielding advice will end completely - unless there is a spike in coronavirus cases.It comes as part of wider easing of lockdown measures, with Boris Johnson keen to get the country back to work to boost the flagging economy. But some experts remain concerned about the impact of a wider reopening of society, as while coronavirus rates have been falling, there have been local outbreaks in places such as Leicester and Blackburn with Darwen. Here are the answers to your questions on the end of shielding. Who was told to shield by the Government   Millions of people received letters from the Government telling them to shield because of their medical history.Doctors drew up a list of conditions likely to make people particularly at risk of being seriously ill with coronavirus.This included organ donor recipients, people with certain types of cancer and those with severe respiratory conditions such as asthma and cystic fibrosis. Pregnant women, some people over s and those who usually need a flu jab to cope with underlying health conditions were also told to shield. However the advice was not compulsory - it was for peopleaposs own protection from the virus. What will change from August From the beginning of August, the Government is pausing advice to people to shield unless there is a spike in coronavirus cases.After months of lockdown, shielded people will be able toto work, to go to the shops, to exercise outside and visit places of worship, as long as they observe social distancing. Children who are deemed clinically vulnerable can go back to school when term begins. However the official advice is still to be careful as the risk of vulnerable people getting severely ill from coronavirus remains. People are told to stay at home as much as you can and continue to take precautions when you do go out. Regular handwashing, avoiding touching your face, and keeping two metres away from people outside is still advised.  Will the support end  Free food parcels, medicine deliveries and care offered to shielded people will stop from August . But vulnerable people can still rely on help from NHS Volunteer Responders to pick up their groceries and prescriptions. You can still get priority slots for online shoppingyou are already registered. What had already changed on July   Vulnerable people were given the go ahead to meet up with up to five friends after months without being allowed to socialise. The Government announced shielded people could form support bubbles with one other household - allowing people to meet inside and outside without social distancing. Those shielding were told they no longer needed to social distance from people living in their own household. WhatI am worried about going back to work   The Government guidance says vulnerable people canto workthey cannot work from home. Employers must ensure that social distancing measures are in place. If you are able to work from home then your boss is expected to help you to do so. From August , shielded people will no longer be able to claim Statutory Sick Pay unless they develop symptoms - in line with the rest of the population. If you cannot work from home, you may be eligible for other forms of leave - but it is at your employeraposs discretion. What about in care homes

title: who can go back work
story: NewsWho can go back to work from Saturday  How work from home rules change on August Big changes are coming for millions of workers in England whove been stuck at home since March. But can your boss force you to go in, and whatyoure shielding, have children or are on furlough  Here are all your questions answeredShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsMillions of workers will now be encouraged back to the office for the first time " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHuge changes for millions of workers in England are coming in from Saturday  August. For months, people have been working at home in kitchens, living rooms and bedrooms due to the threat of coronavirus. But from Saturday, firms can for the first time ask people to come into the office, evenitaposs not absolutely necessary for them to be there. It will be a wave of relief for millions cooped up at home - and for the workers in stricken city-centre pubs. But for others it will be a time of great worry as they juggle childcare, health issues and worries about a second wave of coronavirus.And the government has refused to guarantee a legal right to work from home - meaning itaposll have to be a conversation you have with your employer. Here are all your questions answered as the rules change in England. What is the guidance right now The current guidance for England is thatyoucanwork from home, you should work from home. If youcanapostdo your job from home, you are advised to go back into your workplacepossible.In , your boss should make your workplace aposCovid-secureapos to reduce the risk of transmission.This means lots of things but can include extra cleaning, seating people further apart, and putting up screens and floor markings. Detailed guides for each type of workplace are here. The exception isyouaposre aposshieldingapos due to being extremely clinically vulnerable to Covid-. If youaposre shielding, you should still work from home or -your employer wonapost pay you - claim Statutory Sick Pay. What is changing on August    Instead of the government telling everyone who can work from home to do so, firms will decide who comes into the workplace.Announcing the change, Boris Johnson said: We are going to give employers more discretion.That could mean of course continuing to work from home, which is one way of working safely and which has worked for many employers and employees. Or it could mean making workplaces safe by following Covid Secure guidelines. Shielding is also ending on August  - more of this below - so many of those .million people will be asked to go back to the workplace at the same time. Why are things changing   Boris Johnson announced the change amid growing fears city centre economies will grind to a halt. Sandwich shops, pubs and restaurants face going bankruptworkers are kept away completely - and with them will go thousands of staff. Coronavirus rates had also been falling steadily before the PMaposs announcement on July , though there have been a number of local outbreaks since.And there is - at least in theory - a decent Test and Trace system in place meaning any office outbreaks can be detected quickly. However, the change isnapost without controversy. The PMaposs own Chief Scientic Advisor Sir Patrick Vallance warned on July : We are still at a time when distancing measures are important. Of the ious distancing measures, working from home remains a perfectly good option for many companies because it is easy to do. A number of companies do not think it is detrimental to productivity, and in that situation I see absolutely no reason to change it. Should I take public transport   People are asked to take alternative means to get to workthey can - walking, cycling or even driving. But people may also now use public transport for non-essential journeys, even though they are encouraged to use other optionspossible. So yes, you may use public transport to get to work. Though you will need to wear a face covering and are advised to avoid rush hourpossible. Can I still work from homeI want   If you can do your job perfectly well from home, you should make that argument to your boss.The government is not ordering everyone to go back to work. Instead, it is saying everyonecango back.In reality, many offices will have far lower capacity than before so many companies are likely to still have some staff working from home. However, ultimately this is a decision for your firm. The big dference is that from August , there is no government rule on keeping you away from HQ - itaposs a conversation you have to have with your boss.  No one can physically force you to go into an office of course. Butyouaposre talking about facing the threat of the sack - then yes, basically they can. As long as the workplace is safe, employers can ask people toto work. Many people may have their usual place of work embedded in their employment contract.And there is not a legal right to demand to work from home. Thereaposs a legal right torequestflexible working, but your company only has to engage with your request properly - they donapost have to grant it.The government says firms should consult closely with their employees on what they decide. But Acas says: If someone refuses to attend work without a valid reason, it could result in disciplinary action. Itaposs a slightly dferent kettle of fishthe workplace is unsafe - more on this below.  Can my boss force me to go backitaposs not safe  No -your workplace is not aposCovid-secureapos, your firm should not be asking you back. However, critics say there is no easy redress for workers who believe bosses are breaking the rules. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman urged firms to take socially responsible” decisions, adding: We’re not prescribing what businesses should do, provided that they make the environment safe. Rogue firms can be reported to the Health and Safety Executive, or workers could bring a complaint or go to arbitration service Acas. And employment lawyer Matt Gingell suggested such issues could end up at an employment tribunal. These can all be y processes which take many months to resolve. He said: If an employee refuses toto the workplace due to the employee reasonably believing imminent and serious danger and is then dismissed for that reason the employee could, depending on the circumstances, have a claim for unfair dismissal. The requirement that the employee has to believe that there is imminent and serious danger, does limit the right. WhatIaposm pregnant or have asthma   If you are pregnant or have asthma, diabetes, heart disease or liver disease, you are classed as clinically vulnerable. This means you are not sick enough to be shielding, but that you are at a higher risk from Covid-. If you fall into this category, you can still go back to work where possible. However, you should take extra care in observing social distancing. If you can work from home, your employer should help you to do so. If you canapost work from home, you should be offered the safest available on-site roles, enabling you to stay  metres away from others. This could mean being placed in a dferent role. If you canapost stay two metres from others, your employer should assess whether this involves an acceptable level of risk. If unacceptable risks cannot be removed, pregnant women are entitled to be suspended on full pay.A full list of conditions for the clinically vulnerable group is here. WhatI have children   There is no extra childcare help that came with the back to work order - despite it starting just as the summer holidays got under way. Parents of the youngest children can get up to  hours a week of free childcare, and schools are being encouraged to run catch-up schemes. Parents are also entitled to up to four weeks per year of parental leave for each child - but this is unpaid. It is also capped at  weeks for each child between birth and their th birthday.Labouraposs Keir Starmer has said the Prime Minister is putting parents in an “impossible position”. He said: Despite ordering millions of parents back to the office, the Prime Minister has refused to provide any extra help for families, penalising parents by putting them in an impossible position.“Parents got a back-to-work notice just as the summer holidays began. But they got no support for structured activities, no summer catch-up schemes, and no support for a childcare sector on its knees. WhatIaposve been shielding   Shielding for .million extremely clinically vulnerable people will end in England on August . There may be exceptions to thisthere is a local outbreak in your area. Please check with your local council. If you have been shielding, the government advises that you canto work from August  -you canapost work from home. However, you should adopt strict social distancing, and remain cautious. WhatIaposm on furlough  Furlough will not end on August  and continues right up to October . However, it will start winding down, with firms having to contribute some of the costs of their workers from August . That means firms are likely to take more staff off furlough or - in the worst-case scenario - make them redundant. This is a conversation you should have with your employer. No new staff can be put on furlough - butyou were furloughed previously, you can be re-furloughed. Again, this is a conversation to have with your boss.

Tragic Kayden Cantlow was killed last Wednesday when he was struck by a train. His devastated family say he was able to get through the barriers onto an overpass in order to take his own le. Kaydenaposs death came just three days after the first anniversary of mum Michelleaposs death from cancer, aged just . Now, Kaydenaposs dad and older brother Francis, , are campaigning to encourage others to open up and talk about their mental health. The family, from Colchester, Essex, want to install a large board on the railway bridge with contact details for the Samaritans.  They have also set up a petition to try and get more barriers put up around the overpass - which links St Anneaposs and St Johnaposs in Colchester - to make it more dficult for people to access it. Kayden, a pupil at The Gilberd School in Colchester, was the youngest of six children - with older brothers Alex, , Jordan, , Nathan, , and Francis, , and sister Sapphire, . His brother Francis said: He was always a mummyaposs boy. He just wanted to be with his mum again. We have spoken to people at The Gilberd School where he went and they have said every bit of footage they have of him, he is grinning and laughing with all his friends. He was not being bullied or anything like that - it was nothing from the outside.  He was quiet but popular. He always had a smile on his face. He found a way of getting through the barriers, so I need to bring awareness to that and get it fixed. If we can get it fixed here then I want to move on and do more and make it safe. I also want to make it normal for people to talk about their mental health.  Men especially find it dficult and tend to bottle it up. That is what happened with Kayden. If you keep things bottled up then eventually it will explode. You can’t keep putting things into an already full bottle. Francis has already been in touch with councillors about the safety issue and is determined to talk about mental health issues in primary schools once they reopen.  And Kaydenaposs dad Vinny, , added that the family had no inkling anything was wrong last Wednesday before Kayden died - and said his son had even posted a letter for him as a favour. Vinny said: He was a quiet lad but he always had a smile. He decided to go be with his mum, he just wanted to be back in her arms. Us sitting around moping is just not going to help anyone. If we can get some awareness out there and help even one person then it will be worth it. If one person is feeling low and sees the number of someone they can talk to, then we have made a dference.  It is what Kayden would have wanted. He was always so kind and helpful. Just days before Kaydenaposs death, Vinny had posted an emotional tribute on Facebook to his we Michelle, a year on from her death. Sharing a photo of her, he had written: Today is the first anniversary of the passing of my beautul we Michelle. Not a day passes that I donapost think of her or talk about her. She is always in my thoughts and my love is as strong as always. Miss you so much darling and I hope Iaposm making you proud. Love you so much.

story: NewsFamily consider camping on beach after finding Spanish hotel closed on arrivalLaura Hodgson and her family were forced to use most of their spending money on paying for new temporary accommodation after being given no warning the hotel was closedShareCommentsByAndrew ToppingRyan Merrield:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsLaura Hodgson with partner Cory Jackson and their children Abbie Hodgson, , Cruz, , and Kyron Jackson, eight " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British family were left contemplating camping on the beach after arriving in Spain to find their hotel deserted with no water in the pool. Cruz Hodgson, from Clton, Nottingham, was hoping to celebrate his th birthday with an unforgettable holiday on the Spanish island - but will now be remembering it for all the wrong reasons. Mum Laura Hodgson, , her three kids and partner Corey Jackson, , were due to stay in Las Piramides hotel after landing on Friday, July . But after finding it deserted they fear they might have to stop on the beach instead. Ms Hodgson says they were left with no answers upon arrival - having been unable to find a contact number for online travel agent Loveholidays in order to find out what to do next. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE  When we saw the hotel we were so shocked, the print factory worker told Nottinghamshire Live. There was dust all over the windows and it looked like it had been closed for months. We walked around the outside of the hotel and noticed there was no water in the pool and there were blankets all over the furniture inside. At the time I tried to get hold of Loveholidays  on the phone and there was no number online, I couldnapost get hold of anyone. We didnapost know what to do - at one point we actually thought we might have to stop on the beach - so we walked around the corner and went into another hotel for help. I canapost fault the guy in that hotel, he was really helpful. He said there had been a few people from our hotel who had turned up asking why it wasnapost open. Ms Hodgson and the family were offered short-term accommodation in the nearby hotel, which totalled € for the five people - nearly all their spending money.  They then got talking to another family in the new hotel who had suffered the same problem at Las Piramides - but had been told in advance that it was closed. The other people managed to find us an emergency contact number for Loveholidays  that wasnapost online, Ms Hodgson added. They helped us get hold of them on the Saturday and  Loveholidays  arranged for us to get another hotel. It wasnapost that far away but we lost  hours of our holiday by ringing around trying to find out why we were supposed to be for the rest of the holiday. The parents say they were glad to have somewhere to stay after the fear of having nowhere, but say they have still had no answers from the company about why they were not informed earlier. Ms Hodgson said her son Cruz, now , had his birthday on the holiday which was ruined by the fear of being stranded in a foreign country. It wouldnapost have been so badit was just me and Cory, but we had three kids so it was really scary, she added. It was my sonaposs birthday and at the time we didnapost know where we would be, so that made it even worse and his birthday was ruined. We have had no answers from  Loveholidays  about why it was closed, Iaposve had no explanation as to why we didnapost find out when we got there. However, the company has supported the family by providing a refund and compensating the money for the temporary hotel accommodation - which Ms Hodgson confirmed has arrived back in her account. The family have, however, been afforded one stroke of luck - arriving back into the UK on Friday, July  and just missing the new two-week quarantine rule on arrivals from Spain - a decision Ms Hodgson describes as stupid. Loveholidays apologised to the family for the inconvenience and said it has seen a number of cases where hotels have not reopened as planned. A spokesperson for the firm said: We understand how frustrating and upsetting it must have been for Ms Hodgson and her family to arrive at their destination to find that their hotel was closed. Unfortunately, the hotel that they were supposed to stay at was due to re-open prior to their arrival, but this did not happen as planned and we were regrettably not informed about this.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA family of four have been left heartbroken after their dream home was destroyed in a suspected arson attack. Dean and Louise Fox, along with their two children, Harry, , and Annabelle, , were set to move into their brand new home in September after saving up years to build it. Dean and Louise bought a plot of land in County Durham and began building their home, which was to be called Harbelle, after their kids, in January. They had hoped the house, which was almost finished, would secure their childrenaposs future until they received a phone call which will haunt them forever in the early hours of July  telling them that it was on fire.  Louise, , told ChornicleLive : Those words will haunt us forever.I just thought someone must have set a little fire next to the house I never imagined how bad it actually was. I just donapost know how anyone can be so heartless. Her husband Dean, , was working  hour days to get the house in Station Town, near Wingate, finished missing out on valuable time with his we and kids. Dean, who is a joiner by trade, said it was his dream to build his own house and wanted to finish it for his children. He said: I was working around the clock to get it done and we were nearly there. Iaposm physically exhausted. I would go to work and then head straight to the house to start work again. I missed out on seeing my kids and we just to get it finished. We were just trying our best to improve our lives and better ourselves. I thought it would secure the future for us and put us in a better position. The driving force behind it was our kids. Our kids were going to be in a better financial place. It was our dream. We loved watching Grand Designs. I just canapost believe whataposs happened, itaposs only just sunk in. The day before it was my daughteraposs fourth birthday so that was ruined too. Recalling the horric day, Dean said he was woken up by a phone call between . and .am to say their house was on fire and immediately rushed down. Little did he know that he didnapost need the keys for the house- because there was hardly any of it left. Dean said: We got a phone call to say: aposYou need to get up here, your house is on fire.apos As I was coming up the lane, I saw blue lights and we had a massive window which was completely gone and I just remember seeing orange, thataposs when I knew it was bad. Louise was Facetiming me and asked me what it was like, I turned the phone around and just said itaposs gone. The first thing my son said to me was: aposYouaposve worked so hard dadapos and he was sobbing his heart out. That will always stick out in my head. Louise was just uncontrollably crying. I just wanted to provide for my kids and now all that has gone. The couple is waiting to have the damage assessed by their home insurance, but fear the payout may not cover the full costs. But to help alleviate some of the financial pressure a fundraising page was set up by a family friend which has so far raised over £, in just a matter of days. The page reads: Myself, family and friends are helpless and can’t take this awful day away butwe can try and pull together as a community to support and relive the family of additional financial stress, then every little helps. This is not charity as the family are proud but it’s friends trying to do what we can in dficult times! We would, therefore, appreciate any contributions, whether that be £ or  hour of your time to help give the family a head start at rebuilding their home after knowing they have poured their le savings and more into building this house! Local residents rushed to the support of the family which they said has helped spur them on. Despite their heartache, the family are determined to start again and have vowed to overcome the devastating fire. Dean said: The reaction of the village was just amazing. Sharon McElroy was given the heartbreaking news that her son Karl would not be coming home  years ago. It came as a complete shock to the family, who knew him as a happy and popular young man.He was just  years old and had been on a night out with his friends but was found dead the following morning, the Manchester Evening News reports.The tragic news hit the family hard and had a particularly profound impact on his younger brother. Lee McElroy was described by his sister Katie Fierro as having a heart of gold and being someone who truly cared for everyone around him. But, on February  this year - four days after celebrating his th birthday - he too was found dead at his mumaposs home in Salford having taken his own le. He was a father to three children aged ,  and eight, as well as another son who tragically died at just a few days old. Leeaposs struggles with depression had plagued him throughout much of his le and his family believe these issues, partly triggered by the death of his much-loved brother, pushed him to turn to alcohol and later cocaine which he became addicted to. At an inquest into his death held this week, Bolton Coroners Court heard that he had regularly spoken about suicide and had once previously been taken to hospital following an overdose. Talking about her son, Sharon said: When he was happy he was very happy and he would do anything for anyone. Nothing was too much trouble. But, she believes Lee struggled to speak about some of the worries that were affecting him and felt like he could not discuss the problems he was having with substances. I think it needs talking about more in schools.  Lee would never admit to having a drinking problem and he would never tell us he was taking drugs. He was hiding it because I think he was ashamed. It was so hard to get him to admit he had a problem. He was embarrassed about it and thataposs just not right. It shouldnapost be like that. After hearing evidence that Lee had been drinking in the days before his death, senior coroner Alan Walsh also read out a message he had sent to his sister Katie that morning. It simply read: My le is spiralling out of control. John McElroy, Sharonaposs eldest son, thinks Leeaposs mental health problems began when he found out his brother had killed himself. We think that was the catalyst and the start of Leeaposs problems, I think it had a massive impact on him, he said Thereaposs  years between me and Lee and thataposs a big gap. I think for him it was a bit like having two separate families. But Lee and Karl were closer in age than me and when he lost Karl, Lee started to struggle. Lee, who loved going for walks and spending time outdoors, was working as a delivery driver when he died but had spent his le in a iety of dferent roles.  John said: Lee was  when his brother died. We didnapost think he had depression at that age but his le wasnapost on the path that he wouldaposve liked. He added: I donapost think thereaposs enough support for young men. Itaposs getting better but thereaposs still a massive stigma around mental health and talking about these things. If youaposre struggling or worried itaposs locked away in the attic and youaposre told to be embarrassed about it. Itaposs getting better now and I think maybe in  years it will be a much better situation for people. When I was at school years agoanyone showed weakness they were ridiculed. Iaposm not sure thataposs the case now but it was then. Following the two horric losses in her le, Sharonaposs youngest child, Katie, has begun to devote much of her time to trying to help other families in a similar situation.She is working to raise money for suicide prevention charity Papyrus and has already generated more than £, in donations for a hike to the top of Scafell Pike.

PC Harper, , was dragged for more than a mile along the country lanes of Berkshire when he became entangled in a tow rope attached to the teenagersapos getaway car. She wrote: I implore you to hear my words, see the facts that are laid out before us, and I ask with no expectations other than hope that you might help me to make these changes be considered, to ensure that Andrew is given the retrial that he unquestionably deserves and to see that the justice system in our country is the solid ethical foundation that it rightly should be. The original trial was abandoned on the day the country went into lockdown in March, while for the retrial Mr Justice Edis ordered extra security measures amid fears of potential juror intimidation.  A female juror was discharged just a day before the remaining  started deliberating on their verdicts after she was seen by a prison officer to mouth Bye boys to the teenagers in the dock. The defendants hugged each other after the verdicts were ed following more than  hours of deliberations. Speaking outside court, Mrs Harper thanked the police and prosecution who had stood in our corner and fought to make sure these men were made to repent for their barbaric crimes. But she criticised the verdicts in the open letter on Facebook, which has been shared more than , times.

Lauren Barton popped down to her local Waitrose last month and picked up the half dozen pack of Clarence Court Braddock Whites Free Range Duck Eggs, for £.. But the -year-old English teacher popped half of the eggs into an incubator she had bought off Amazon to seeshe could hatch a duckling. And to Laurenaposs delight,  days later, one of the eggs in the incubator started to show cracks - and after an intense  hours of hatching, a tiny little duckling popped out. Lauren, from Ipswich, Suffolk, has named the fluffy little chick Darwin - and says it is just like having a dog. She said: Heaposs gorgeous. Heaposs so friendly, he loves us completely. Heaposs like a little dog - heaposs so loyal and just follows us around everywhere, and wants attention all the time. I think he thinks heaposs a human, or weaposre ducks. The box of eggs only cost £., and the incubator cost less than £. It was certainly an experiment, but it was well worth it. Lauren, who teaches at Copleston High School in Ipswich, Suffolk, said she got the idea after reading another news story about someone who had also hatched supermarket eggs recently. She said: No-one in my family thought it was a good idea, because they said ducks are messy and hard work. My partner really didnapost want me to do it. But I loved the idea, so I went ahead and did it.  The incubation was actually quite laborious, itaposs quite intense. The eggs spend a month in the incubator, but you have to turn them three times a day every day, and then you have to mist the eggs towards the end to keep their temperature right. Thereaposs a lot of work involved. Itaposs not like I could go out for the day and leave them to it. Lauren bought the smallest size of incubator she could find - meaning she could only fit three of the eggs into it, and had to throw away the other three eggs. She said: I was shocked when I saw that two of the three I put into the incubator were viable and were growing. We werenapost really expecting it to work.  And even though Darwin was the only duck that made it in the end, Lauren said that she had to wait a long  hours for him to emerge - and that she didnapost think he was going to survive. She said: On the day that he started cracking, it was my last day of teaching at school before the summer, and I was meant to be going out the next night with some of the other staff. But when he still hadnapost come out the next day, I had to text them to say I didnapost think I was going to be able to make it out. I did go in the end, but I had to cut it short to go home and check on the duckling. I stayed up really late that night, and then went to sleep for a few hours and woke up again and in the end I had to help him out a little bit. They say youaposre supposed to leave them to break through the egg themselves, but I did help him along a bit - and then there he was.

title: mystery surrounds north korea ghost
story: NewsMystery surrounds North Korea ghost ships washing up in Japan full of dead bodiesA study by non-profit Global Fishing Watch has helped to shed some light on the deadly phenomenon, which has seen rickety fishing vessels from North Korea washing up in Japan for yearsShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  JUL NewsRickety fishing vessels from North Korea have been washing up in Japan for years " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe mystery surrounding North Korean aposghost shipsapos which have been washing up in Japan full of dead bodies may now have been finally solved. For years, Japanaposs north coast had been the site of the disturbing phenomenon, with rickety fishing vessels arriving more than ,km from where they set out. In  the numbers were unprecedented with more than  damaged boats landing, containing a total of  bodies, compared to  vessels the year before.Some have speculated the weather that year was to blame and that North Koreaaposs aging fishing population had something to do with the problem. But a study by non-profit Global Fishing Watch and published today in journal Science Advances has been able to shed some light on the matter.Researchers used satellite technologies to analyse marine traffic in northeast Asia in  and , and discovered hundreds of dark fishing fleets - believed to be Chinese - have been operating in North Korean waters - apparently illegally. This meant ushering out North Korean boats and forcing them on ill-advised ventures into Russian and Japanese waters, poorly equipped for long distance travel.  For foreigners, fishing in waters off the North Korean coast or trading fish caught there internationally is against the law - but it doesnapost appear to have deterred the huge swathes of rogue ships, according to the report. The paperaposs authors estimate in  and  alone these ships caught more than , metric tons of Pacic flying squid, a particularly valuable seafood - worth £ million. Jaeyoon Park, a senior data scientist at Global Fishing Watch and co-lead author of the study, said: It is the largest known case of illegal fishing perpetrated by vessels originating from one country operating in another nationaposs waters. Another author, Jungsam Lee, said the North Korean vesselsapos decision to try their luck in distant foreign waters would have proved catastrophic for many of the fisherman.  It is too dangerous for them to work in the same waters as the Chinese trawlers, he explained. Thataposs why theyaposre pushed to work in Russian and Japanese waters and that explains why some of North Koreaaposs damaged vessels showed up on the beaches of Japan. Northeast Asiaaposs waters are some of the most contested seas in the world, but fish stocks are in dramatic decline. The Pacic flying squid stocks have dropped  per cent in South Korean waters and  per cent Japanese waters since , according to Global Fishing Watch.

story: NewsThousands of North Koreans ignore distancing at Kim celebration despite coronavirus casePictures from Pyongyang show war veterans - many appearing to be in their s and s - cheering Kim Jong-un as crowds gathered to mark the anniversary of the Korean War endingShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsLarge groups of North Korean veterans cheer Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang on Monday " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWorrying pictures show thousands of North Koreans packed together cheering Kim Jong-un - despite the country confirming its first suspected Covid- case. There was no social distancing as former soldiers - many of them appearing to be in their s and s - gathered for the th National Conference of War Veterans yesterday. And large crowds gathered for celebrations marking the anniversary of the end of the Korean War in capital Pyongyang.Veterans were seen clapping as dictator Kim - who earlier this year was rumoured to have gone into hiding at the start of the coronavirus pandemic - delivered a speech.Large crowds gathered in the streets to witness firework displays to mark the anniversary. At the end of last week a state of emergency was declared as the country said it has its first suspected Covid- case. Up to now, North Korea has denied having a single case, despite more than , testing positive in neighbouring South Korea. Kim imposed a lockdown on the border city of Kaesong, calling it a critical situation in which the vicious virus could be said to have entered the country, state news agency KCNA added. The North claims the patient was a defector who re-entered from the South to flee rape allegations. There was no evidence of social distancing as Kim bragged about his countryaposs nuclear capabilities.  He said: Now, weaposve changed to a country which can defend itself reliably and unwaveringly against high-intensity pressures and military threats and blackmailing by imperialistic reactionaries and hostile forces. North Korea has received thousands of coronavirus testing kits from Russia and other countries, and imposed strict border closures.

title: alphabet zoo to help raise funds for dundee dog shelter
story: Dundee#s unique animal alphabet zoo is set to raise funds for the city#s homeless dog shelter.Artist Clare Stansfield created the alphabet zoo in her garden in Old Craigie Road at the beginning of July just for a bit of fun.Over  days, Clare, , has designed and created  wooden animals beginning with consecutive letters of the alphabet.Now she has decided to auction them off to raise money for Brown Street Kennels.Clare said: #The zoo was a bit of fun but it attracted loads of attention when I began displaying the animals in my garden.#Someone asked me what I was planning to do with the animals now that I had completed the entire alphabet.#Fundraising hadn#t been my intention, but it did seem like a great idea so I had a think about what I could raise money for and how I could do it.#Clare said she was keen for the letters to support an animal charity or centre of some kind.She said: #I have a dog, Hudson, a black Labrador and we have sometimes donated money, food and toys to Brown Street Kennels, so I thought I would like any money raised to go there.#Clare thought the best way to raise money would be to auction the animals off.She said: #I had no idea how popular they would be.#I thought that evenI raised £ it would be something to give to the kennels.#However, I have so far sold around  of them and already raised around £. title: dundee united 1 kilmarnock 1 cammy smith ready to push for premiership place after making most of lockdown
story: Dundee United goalscorer Cammy Smith has revealed how lockdown has helped get him ready to push for his place.Smith took less than a minute to hit the target for the Tangerines as they drew - in their final pre-season friendly against Kilmarnock behind closed doors at Tannadice on Saturday.Micky Mellon’s men pressurised Killie’s trialist keeper and his mishit clearance landed at the feet of United striker Lawrence Shankland.The Scotland star picked out Smith on the edge of the area and he dashed into the box before sliding the ball into the net.It was certainly a loud and clear message to new boss Mellon that Smith wants to be more heavily involved this time than he was under previous gaffer Robbie Neilson.Indeed, his th and final appearance for United last season was away to Queen of the South on January  and he was subsequently sent out to Irish club Dundalk on loan.Smith revealed that while the coronavirus shutdown has been a dreadful experience for Scottish football, he has made the most of it.“Lockdown has probably helped me,” he told the club’s Arabzone.“I used it in the right way.“When I was at home I used the time to get fitter and clear the head, really.“Last season was tough and I was sent out on loan.“It wasn’t easy but even when the previous managerwas here I came back and got stuck right back into training.“It was a shock when he left but the new manager has come in and been really good with the boys.“He has spoken well and he has that way about him that has gotten the players onside.“You don’t want to go out there and let him or your teammates down.“Since he has come in the tempo has been gone up.“We weren’t really training at that pace.“The gameshave been competitive and there has been tackling, with boys coming off with knocks and stuff like that.“It has been realistic.“That is what happens on a Saturday so that’s what you need.“If you do that during the week in training then come the weekend there are no surprises.“It is early days, obviously, but I aim to keep focused and be pushing on so that I can be part of things here.”Killie eventually recovered from that early blow to equalise through a Greg Kiltie deflected goal just a minute into the second half.It was the newly-promoted Tangerines’ fourth friendly against Premiership sides, following on from fixtures against Motherwell, Livingston and Rangers.Smith added: “It was a good exercise for us.“We have had three very competitive games close together.“I think the past week has been tough for the boys: Livingston, Rangers and then Kilmarnock.“It is all geared towards next Saturday and I think the players and management have gotten everything they wanted out of it.“It has been a dficult pre-season, obviously, with what has been going on but it’s been very good because we have gotten the work done that we needed to get done.“The games have also been very competitive.“They haven’t had that friendly feel to them.“Even this one – it felt like a competitive game.“It has given us a right good look at Premiership opposition. “We have seen what we will be up against and we know ourselves that we can compete.”Next up is the real deal – the curtain-raiser against St Johnstone at Tannadice this Saturday.Smith said: “We are going into the new season in the right frame of mind and looking forward to it.“We just can’t wait to get going.“We will now recover and have a full week’s training to build up to St Johnstone on Saturday.“There is a lot more to come from us so we need to focus and be ready.“Going into that match, everyone will be fighting to get into the team.“There will be that competitive edge.“If you do get a chance to impress then you have to take it because there are plenty of players here who are hungry to get in. title: judges face task of choosing aberdeens champions
story: The judges for The Evening Express Aberdeen’s Champion Awards can be revealed today.Five experts, who boast a wealth of knowledge and experience in ious industries, make up this year’s .The judges include Balmoral Group’s public relations manager Steve Gibb, ACVO’s funding and sustainability officer Alison Chandler and Hampton’s managing director and Celebrate Aberdeen founder Morven Mackenzie.They will also be joined by Evening Express editor Craig Walker and Original FM#s daytime presenter Martin Ingram to examine this year’s entries.The Evening Express Aberdeen’s Champion Awards, which celebrate big-hearted iniduals and businesses helping vulnerable people in the north-east communities, are run in association with Balmoral Group and Original FM. vw, px"  The judges will have the dficult task of choosing finalists in each of the eight categories # Community Champion, Entertainment Champion, Business Champion, Young Person’s Champion, Sport and Wellbeing Champion, Charity Champion – sponsored by subsea market intelligence company Archer Knight, Keyworker Awardand Keyworker Award .Evening Express editor Craig Walker said he was amazed at the number and quality of entries received so far.He stated: “We’ve been amazed at the number of entries we’ve received so far.“There’s clearly a lot of people and organisations out there who have gone above and beyond during the coronavirus crisis.#The judges are going to have a very dficult job picking the winners.”Original FM’s daytime presenter Martin Ingram would like to wish all nominees the best of luck.He public relations manager, said that while he was looking forward to the judging process, he was certain it was going to be a “hugely dficult task” to pick the finalists.He said: “You hear so many stories of kindness, compassion and caring in our communities and it will be a privilege to be among those choosing the very best initiatives for recognition.” vw, px"  Hampton’s managing director and time.#The vast majority do so without expecting any recognition, but that#s something they definitely deserve, so it#s great to have The Evening Express Aberdeen’s Champion Awards to do just that and title: plans to convert former north east homebase store in to two retail units approved
story: Proposals to turn a former north-east hardware store into two retail units have been approved by council bosses.Halliday Fraser Munro lodged the proposals on behalf of Gatsby Aberdeen Ltd with Aberdeenshire Council for the former Homebase site at Portlethen in May.They set their vision to split the unit into two dferent stores with one being home to a food retailer and the other would be a iety retailer.Work would include creating  disabled parking bays, and  for parent and child parking.Now planning chiefs at Aberdeenshire Council have given their support to the project despite an objection from a nearby slaughterhouse.But a report by the local authority said environmental health officials had no issues with the plans.It said: #While representation has been made by the adjacent business premise, the nature of the works proposed are in most part minor elevational alterations to the existing building, as opposed to a complete new build structure in#As such, it is expected that the timescale for the specied workswould actually be for a  short timeframe, and notwithstanding, the developer would have to accord with general accepted working practices for construction hours.#Through consultation with environmental health, they have confirmed that they have no objection to the proposals and that the proposed development is in keeping with the previous use of the unit when it operated as Homebase.#The report concluded the changes to the former hardware store were #minor works# and would not have a major impact on the surrounding area.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead

title: crinan canal prepares for phased re opening
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Crinan Canal, dubbed #Scotland#s most beautul shortcut# is preparing to re-open to navigation from July .Scottish Canals this week updated interested parties on plans for its waterways network as coronavirus lockdown continues to ease.In a statement, Scottish Canals said: #Since we last wrote to you, the First Minister announced phase two of the easing of lockdown restrictions on Thursday June , and so we wanted to update you on Scottish Canals# ongoing response to COVID- in light of this.#Phase two will see an increase in the volume of outdoor work being carried out by our operational team in areas such as vegetation management, weed-cutting, litter-picking and channel clearance to prepare the canals for navigation.#Our offices, visitor centres, indoor cafes, holiday accommodation, and locks and bridges remain closed until phase three, with the majority of our staff continuing to work from home.#During phase one we welcomed back leisure boaters living within five miles of their mooring and residential boaters to use the canals for local boating. However, there are still numerous restrictions in place, including no operation of locks and bridges, limited services and limited staff available on the ground. This remains the position.#We are, however, pleased to let you know that Scottish Canals is planning to re-open canals to navigation in line with the announcement that Scotland’s tourism sector is preparing to reopen during phase three of the Scottish Government route map on July . Subject to the confirmation of phase three from that date, the canals will open to navigation as follows:While boats will be able to transit the canals, the operating hours and days still have to be confirmed#When the canals were closed to navigation at the beginning of lockdown, mooring customers received three months# navigation licence free of charge to June .Scottish Canals added: #We have decided to extend the concession to cover July, with mooring customers getting a credit note issued to their account next month in addition to April, May and June.#A deferment of boat safety certicates has also been further extended until September.With health and safety in mind, Scottish Canals will adopt strict social distancing, segregation and hygiene measures to minimise the risk of transmitting Covid- for the foreseeable future, including cough screens at transaction points, queue management and clear signage to remind people of the importance of physical distancing and good hand and cough hygiene.

title: letters to the editor july 3 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Communities on the A are blighted by the noise of bikers, many with illegal exhausts.Inveraray is the gathering point for motorcyclists and on a recent Saturday during lockdown around  were gathered, not two metre social distancing, and failing to adhere to the maximum eight in a group guidance.This has become the norm throughout the summer, and it seems lockdown guidance does not apply to bikers as they have been a constant feature on the roads, even in phase one.The unofficial Argyll TT goes past our homes most weekends over the spring and summer months.I have a bike licence and understand the feeling of freedom, but three-figure speeds past residential entrances, many of them hidden, is completely unacceptable.As a resident you begin to dread the weekend and sunny days. The noise is constant and intrusive for  –  hours in a day, the decibel level in excess of  dB where sounds above  dB are harmful to hearing.This is a serious issue for residents who cannot open their doors and windows, cannot use their gardens, pets are terried, it is often impossible to have a conversation, or a phone call. The noise from hundreds of bikes is explosive and destructive.The speeds are terrying, they travel in intimidating packs, the noise is threatening and the bikers have no respect for the communities they are speeding through. They pass multiple residential entrances with limited sight lines with no care for risk. The offensive noise seems to come from two actions modying motorbike exhausts and extreme acceleration in legal bikes.If a car made a similar noise, spewed out the same polluting omissions, or did the same ridiculous speeds they would be pulled over by the police, but bikers appear above the law.As technology reduces the noise pollution of cars, planes and other forms of transport, it seems motorbikes are exempt. Bikers claim #loud pipes save lives# but is safety really the motivation for deliberately creating excessive noise Noise counts as a statutory nuisance it either unreasaonably and substantially interferes with the user or enjoyment of a home or other premises or is likely to injure health.The problem on A is known to all the statutory agencies, but nothing is done.If this is a national problem, what action needs to be taken Concerned Loch Fyne-side resident Sir,I am not qualied to judge economic competence, but considering the party he represents, I think that Councillor Redman might find it advisable to be wary of the phrase #colossal mismanagement# .For my part, I would consider a degree of incompetence to be preferable to the great damage caused over the last decade to  per cent of the UK’s people, as well as to its institutions and its reputation by the cruel, self-serving, xenophobic, elitist, dishonestregime currently in Westminster.Name supplied, LochgilpheadSir,Our charity#s support for blind and partially sighted people affected by the coronavirus lockdown has received a £, boost from the Scottish Government#s Wellbeing Fund.With this extra funding we will be able to support an additional  people and respond to the increased demand for more in-depth, one-to-one emotional support.The practical and psychological effects of losing your sight can have a signicant impact on people’s well-being, and this current situation has exacerbated the anxiety and isolation felt by many.Access to essential services such as food and medicines is more dficult as is social distancing, vital information on staying safe isn#t always in accessible formats, and many of our older members aren#t always confident about using new technology to stay in touch with others.Everyone accessing RNIB#s confidential counselling service will receive eight weekly sessions with an accredited counsellor, delivered via telephone and online, with each session normally lasting an hour.The funding will enable us to reduce the waiting list for emergency mental health sessions and also let existing clients access additional sessions.The RNIB helpline is available on   .James Adams, RNIB Scotland directorSir,Every pub across Scotland should be allowed to stock and sell beer from local independent brewers, to help them recover post-lockdown.CAMRA, the Campaign for Real Ale has launched the #Cheers for Choice# campaign.The campaign wants these arrangements to be relaxed, and MSPs are also being urged to support the Tied Pubs Bill being put forward in the Scottish Parliament by Labour MSP Neil Bibby. The legislation would give tied pub tenants protections in law, including a right to be able to sell guest beers in their pubs.Allowing small and independent brewers to sell into all pubs will also improve consumer choice and allow pub-goers to support local brewing businesses.It also makes business sense, with  per cent of pub-goers saying they would be less likely to go back to a pubit doesn’t have a range of brews from small and independent producers.Sarah Crawford, CAMRA Director for Scotland, Kirkcaldy

title: could a two way conversation transform scotlands health
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSome of us have learned in lockdown the importance of other people, and have been longing for these first personal contacts.There have been surprises in discovering just what is important in le, and the comfort of knowing you are not alone in your likes, as your favourite brand of chocolate is again sold out.We have also been made aware that the way we behave makes a dference to the future. It has taken a national emergency to get the government to acknowledge that it needs our compliance and, for that, must give us the information we need.Suddenly the choices we make are seen as vitally important, and we have a part to play in achieving success for ourselves and our community. Can this be a foundation for a future partnership that could transform the health of Scotland and the pressure on our services As a physiotherapist I became aware that there was little that one could do to impose solutions there had to be a relationship that involved two way listening, mutual trust and support to do what was necessary. In this pandemic Nicola Sturgeon has said that we have behaved in a way that saved lives and protected the NHS.When this is over we could be at the beginning of another le-altering journey.It will demand a huge sht in expectations. There is an amazing bias in society towards the idea of decrepitude and dependency in old age, when in fact encouraging dependency increases a slide into that very state. During past months many of these attitudes have been exposed and caused outrage but they are long standing and deep seated.If you have been trying to escape into fiction you might have no better idea of what is possible. Alison Flood interviewed crime writers about their work, and this is what she found.Ian Rankin is now writing about a John Rebus who has health issues, James Lee Burke has his detective Robicheaux meditating on mortality in his early s and Mark Billingham has slowed his Tom Thorne down a bit because he is in his s. Michael Connelly does not believe that it is credible to have his Harry Bosch with a badge and gun and still working for the LAPD, this in a country where the President is  and one of the presidential hopefuls .Worst of all, Sara Paretsky created a feisty, strong woman for her books, only to succumb to popular misconceptions and stop her age at  because she didn#t #want Vi to be helpless#.These fictional creations battle the evils they see in their society. title: tuning into nature and getting down to business
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn normal circumstances busy lives and work schedules often get in the way of finding time to connect with nature, to be able to immerse oneself in the muffled sounds within a forest, seas crashing on rocky shores or the wind blowing the lonesome notes of a curlew across the moor.When did you last hear the bark of deer, watch an otter hunting for fish to take to its young or spot the smooth glide of a golden eagle overhead  Have you noticed how tree branches reach to the sunlight or bend to the wind and did you know you can use such traits to help navigate  Have you gazed at the starlit skies on a clear night and been able to name the constellations or point to the North Star  Have you ever foraged for wild ingredients and flowers to create a new culinary delight For many the tragedy of a world in the throes of a pandemic has brought around a very dferent pause, allowing time to tune once more into nature, evensuch a pause is brief. Perhaps for the first time in their lives they have heard the bark of deer or spotted something in nature that is totally new to them. And many will have seen footage of the animals and creatures that tentatively stepped into urban settings whilst humankind remained under lockdown.But that is changing as we ease back into a new normality.Economics and peoples’ livelihoods are, of course, firmly entwined with modern day living, human survival and wellbeing it is extremely important that we find a route to recovery and many are suffering deeply. But what we do not want to do is fall back into the same old traps that were so detrimental to the wildle, nature and ecosystems of our planet. Finding a way forward and a new balance is not just crucial for other species but for that of our own children and future generations too.Many will have been shocked at the sudden increase in fly tipping during lockdown plus the thoughtless parking and abandonment of picnic rubbish, disposable barbecues and indiscriminate toileting as lockdown eased. All have grave consequences for wildle and nature.The result is the burning, choking, strangling, trapping or poisoning of animals, birds, plants and aquatic le.Taking care of our surroundings and appreciating nature is a real joy. Teaching children the beauty of the outdoors and how to care for it can bring a lelong love for natureyou love something you usually wish to protect it.And learning never stops for any of us. Sometimes it is the basics that are needed before we move on to the complexities of natural navigation or learning our stars.So for this month here is one tip : learn how to go to the toilet in the outdoors!Doing this responsibly and teaching your children makes for a lelong enjoyment of walking and exploring without the bane of wondering where the next toilet is. I know many people who find it incredibly dficult, not great when in the middle of nowhere miles from home.In a nutshell the key is to carry out all paper and sanitary waste in a sealable bag, to go aMountaineering Scotland has excellent online guidance on how to dispose of your natural waste.I hope, like me, you will wish to continue to enjoy nature and take the time to care for and immerse your senses in this beautul world we live in.

title: when inveraray might have had a railway
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle + had a railwayviaYOURTWITTERNAMEHERE" title"Tweet this"TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLetters dating back to the first half of the th century reveal that there was once a proposed railway line to Inveraray from Dalmally.Letters in the Inveraray Castle archives, housed at the estate#s Cherry Park, shed some light on why the seventh and eighth Duke of Argyll each opposed the building of this branch line across their lands.In , the seventh duke was #quite confounded at the mania of the people of Inveraray and Oban, proposing a plan of a rail road by Inveraray and Oban to all the world, to carry a few black cattle and salt herring…pray assure them of my unqualied opposition, in and out of parliament to such a wild goose plan##Lord Lorne, his son and the future eighth Duke of Argyll, was also unhappy about #this ridiculous railway scheme#. In , he wrote: #The country presents obstacles whichsuperable at all are so only by an enormous outlay.#…I cannot conceive the dference of level between Loch Awe and the top of the Cladich hill being surmounted unless by a tunnel of most preposterousand dficulty.#The traffick except during the tourist months would be chieflynot entirely confined to sheep and cattle…and…there are already natural facilities of water carriage greater than is possessed by any county in Scotland.#Inveraray is resorted to chiefly on account of its beauty – which would not be improved by a railway passing up Glenaray – as to its amenity as a family residence, cutting up Glenaray would be a most serious damnication. It is now one of the most beautul drives in the place, and as a drive it would be destroyed.#The line from Glasgow to Oban took  years to build and finally opened in , proving extremely popular with holidaymakers for many years. The proposed branch line from Dalmally to Inveraray was never built, despite plans to #hide# the railway from the duke’s view. A plan from  shows a proposed tunnel to carry the line through the duke’s policies near to the castle. This proposal, like many others, was defeated in the House of Lords.Instead, provision was made at Dalmally for a waiting room, the #Duke’s Room#, at Dalmally Station where visitors arriving by train could await the arrival of a carriage in comfort.This is just one of innumerable fascinating stories stored within the Argyll Papers, the family and estate archive of the Campbell family, dukes of Argyll.The Friends of the Argyll Papers was established to support the development of the archive and to promote its use and enjoyment by a wide audience.It has been described as one of the most important private archives in Britain, offering a rich resource for Scottish and British history from the th to the st centuries. Prior to the pandemic it was attracting visitors from all over the world, researching a wide range of subjects including family and local history, Gaelic studies, place names, military history, political history, economic and social history, agriculture and industry, architecture and more.You can support the preservation and development of this important archive by joining the Friends via the group#s website, and more information is available on the Friends of The Argyll Papers Facebook page.Article written by archivist for the Argyll Papers, Alison Diamond
