title: gala-fairydean-rovers-rename-bar-legend-volunteer
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers have re-named the bar in their clubrooms after volunteer Alan Allison.The new signs unveiling took place in the clubrooms on Sunday for his th birthday.For almost a decade Alan has manned the bar voluntarily every weekend serving refreshments to members and visitors.Apart from the current pandemic which forced the closure of the bar from March, he has only missed one sht ndash a Saturday in May  when he was at Hampden to see Hibernian lt the Scottish Cup.Gala Fairydean Rovers chairman Ryan Cass said:"Alan is a legend at the club and no-one deserves this more than him."With his th birthday coming up this week, we felt it was appropriate to re-name the bar in his honour."The Alan Allison bar reopened last weekend.Meanwhile on the playing front Gala Fairydean Rovers first team resume training this weekend so they will be fully prepared for the new Lowland League campaign which is expected to get underway at the start of October.

title: galashiels-author-alan-windram-set-borders-book-festival
story: ROBOT dancing, singalongs and an exclusive look inside One Button Bennysnew adventure are all in store this weekend.Author Alan Windram, who is originally from Galashielsis bringing the second instalment of the award-winning story to the Borders Book Festival in the first reading of the to-be-released picture book.And Windram has ensured the region is front and centre with this book.Although set in space, talented Borderers have helped with the creation of the story."Basically, I wrote it Chloe [Holwill-Hunter] illustrated it, and weve got Jack Lowden who has read the audiobook for us," he explained."Jack read the audiobook for the first book, and hes also kindly read the audiobook for the second book."Windrams connections to his collaborators go back years, as he met Lowden while performing in local amateur dramatics groups.Holwill-Hunter was a classmate of Lowdens when they were schoolchildren.When askedbringing Borders talent to the fore was part of his writing plans, Windram said that initially, it was serendipitous to work with Holwill-Hunter.He said: "Jacks mum, at the time, ran the Flat Cat Cafeacute in Lauder, we used to go there and Chloe was a waitress there."I saw some of the illustrations she had done and thought, wow these are amazing, it would be lovely to do a picture book ndash so it all happened by chance."We [with Holwill-Hunter] did our first picture book called a Puppys Taletogether and then after that we did the first One Button Benny."I knew Jack through the Gala Opera. So I thought, why dont I seeJack will read the audiobook, so it all kind of happened by chance."One Button Benny, and even the storys sequel, One Button Benny and the Gigantic Catastrophe, all come with le lessons for their young readers, something which Windram was keen to include in his writing."All the books I write have some kind of moral emphasis," he added. "The story of One Button Benny, well the first one, was about a little robot who gets bullied and teased."Kids can often relate to that, although its a robot, they can relate to that as things that happen."The first book is very much about that everybody is special and everybody is unique, everybody has something to give as well."The second book takes it a little bit further, continuing with those themes, but also its about friendship. Its about working together, but its also about saying sorry when maybe something happens or you do something wrong."Alan Windrams book event, Bennys Back, will be streamed live on Sunday, August  at am via the Borders Book Festival, where he will perform two original songs about Benny, two readings, including an exclusive look at the new One Button Benny and the Gigantic Catastrophe, all with the then sunny Highlands as a backdrop.For more information on the event, with links to other events during the festivals Family Series, visit: bordersbookfestival.org online-event alan-windram-bennys-back

title: former-polish-shop-galashiels-converted-housing
story: AN APPLICATION to turn a former grocery store in Galashiels into two homes has been given the green light.The Polish Shop, at  High Street, will be turned into a flat and a two-storey house.Scottish Borders Councils lead planning officer Carlos Clarke said that although the shop was in the town centre, it was "well outwith the Core Activity Area".He added: "I recognise the loss of the retail use, but also note the building has had non-retail uses in the recent past ."I accept the residential use may be a less vibrant contributor to the town centre, and that there are no other ground floor residential uses fronting the High Street."However, a residential use will, nonetheless, be a positive contributor, and this shop comprises an unremarkable and modest property located at the end of the town centre, well away from the principal activity area of the town."There is also a range of uses in this part of town already, including residential uses on upper floors."A residential use on the ground floor would have a negligible effect on the strength of the town centre overall and the character of this end of the town, and would maintain the mixed use nature of this area."

title: stunning-570k-airdrie-mansion-sauna-grabs-2-50-raffle-competition
story: A STUNNING pound, mansion could be yours thanks to a unique competiton - with entries costingjust pound. a ticket.The concept is simple ndash anyone over the age of  can enter the competition by answering one question, paying the pound. entry fee, and a winner is drawn using a number generating algorithm.The cap for ticket entrants is set at , tickets before the planned draw.Thiswas meantto take place in March, but has been postponed to December as a result of the coronavirus.Philip Leckie, who lived in the five-bedroom detached house at  AlexanderStreet, Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, for nearly a decade, has received interest from across the globe with his alternative and ldquomore creative way to pass on the property to a new owner.He said:ldquoWe got surveyors in who said it was worth around pound, ndash but wersquod be lucky to get pound, for it, maybe less.ldquoI thought to myself, lsquothere must be another way of doing thisrsquo.It was at that point that Philip came up with the idea of holding a competition ndash and is even planning to donate a large portion of the money raised to Airdriersquos local St Andrewrsquos Hospice.The home includes a sauna,large lounge, conservatory, sun lounge and full attic space.There is also a detached garage with a driveway fit for multiple cars.He continued: ldquoMy grandshyfather died in St Andrewrsquos Hospice about  years ago, and the hospice staff were always more than helpful ndash not just for my grandfather but for the entire family.ldquoThey are just amazing, even seeing the way they cared for Fernando Ricksen in his final months was incredible and inspiring. So I thought about this idea, trying to do something a bit dferent.ldquoIrsquove now committed to giving them around pound, after this."Mr Leckie added: ldquoWe really didnrsquot expect that people in Vegas or New York would be interested in a house in Airdrie, but there you are.ldquoItrsquos strange, but itrsquos picked up interest across the globe which is great.ldquoIf you look at the odds, the odds of winning this pound, house are a lot better than winning the lottery, thatrsquos just facts.He added: ldquoIt is a magnicent house and is fully renovated.ldquoItrsquos not like yoursquore winning a derelict house, itrsquos in walk-in condition.You can enter at drawahouse.

title: vans-trailers-given-green-light-recycling-centres
story: VANS and trailers will now be given access to Borders recycling centres on an appointment basis.Launching today, Scottish Borders Councilhas created an online booking system which will allow owners of large vans and trailers to transport waste to local recycling centres.This new development is part of SBCs phasedto its normal recycling and waste disposal services.Chief executive at SBC, Tracey Logan, said: "We know that owners of large vans and trailers have been keen to start using recycling centres again for a number of weeks, and we thank them for their patience."Bookings for large van, or trailer disposals can be made up to a week in advance or with a minimum of two days notice. Commercial access is still not granted.Large vans, such as a Ford Transit, are defined as being two tonnes in weight when carrying the maximum permitted load. Small  vans, such as a Ford Courier, do not need to book in advance.The free booking system noties householders that they should arrive promptly to their booked slot, however,there is a queue they will still be granted access, even after their allotted time.Borderers are asked not to queue beyond signs at entrances to avoid unnecessary queueing.If vehicles arrive at a centre with no booking, they will not be allowed entry.The pre-existing waste quantity restrictions remain in place - a maximum of five bin bags of waste including a limit of two large items.Other restrictions, such as one householder per visit is allowed to exit a vehicle, and staff are unable to offer help to remove waste from vehicles.Ms Logan added: "We know that owners of large vans and trailers have been keen to start using recycling centres again for a number of weeks, and we thank them for their patience.ldquoWe need to ensure we minimised signicant delays and potential social distancing issues for public and staff using the sites, which is why we have been working on a booking system which is now ready to use.ldquoAll large van and trailer owners must make a booking before arriving at a recycling centre. The booking form is straightforward to use and will take five minutes to complete.ldquoOur recycling centres remain very busy andthere is a considerable queue the public is asked to consider coming back to a site at another time.For more information, including opening times and the online booking form for large vans and trailers, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk recyclingcentres

title: galashiels-business-park-sold-8-6m
story: A BUSINESS park in Galashiels has been sold for pound. million.It was announced today that M Real Estate has bought the Galabank Business and Trade Park at Wilderhaugh.The complex currently hosts firms such as Kyowa Kirin International PLC, Momentum Scotland, CubeLtd, Jewson, City Plumbing Supplies, City Electrical Factors, Rexel UK and Dingbro.Jamie Thain of Galbraith, who concluded the sale on behalf of Abercastle Investments, said: ldquoThe investment attracted good interest due to its signicance within the location, quality of accommodation and strong tenant line up."It not only provides high quality modern office accommodation within the town but has also attracted many of the UKrsquos largest trade counter operators who have clustered within the park and trade well from it due to Galashielsrsquo central geographical location within the Scottish Borders."It is a clear example of continued investor appetite for well-presented investments with ongoing asset management potential, even in these unprecedented times.

title: lane-closed-jedburgh-new-crossing
story: ONE lane of the A in Jedburgh at the Abbey Bridge End junction will be closed from Friday for a new pedestrian crossing and resurfacing work.The lane will be closed from .pm on July  until am on August .A spokesperson from Amey, who monitor Borders trunk roads said: "These essential works, with a value of pound,, will improve safety and connectivity for pedestrians and wheelchair users, as well as improving the ride quality for road users at this location."The safety of workers remains a top priority during this essential maintenance project. Physical distancing protocols, in line with Scottish Government guidance, will be in place to ensure all on-site personnel remain safe throughout the duration of the project. Thorough risk assessments will be carried out and cleansing stations will be implemented on site."

title: bike-repair-voucher-website-struggles-launch
story: Boris Johnsonrsquos ambitious plan to get Britons cycling has got off to a rocky start, with the website offering bicycle repair vouchers crashing at launch.As part of the Prime Ministerrsquos pound billion scheme to boost active travel, the Government has made some , Fix Your Bike vouchers available to be used for standard servicing and replacing components.The website, fixyourbikevoucherscheme.est.org.uk, was due to go live at .pm on Tuesday night.However, initial efforts to access the site ed only an ldquoError  message.The scope of the problem quickly became title: double-decker-bus-cafe-set-park-prestonpans
story: The proposals have been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council, with the bus to be sited at the eastern end of Prestonpans, off the B.Matsform Ltd, the company behind the plans, told the local authority that the vehicle could be in a colour ldquosympathetically chosen to complement the coastal character of the site.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe applicant has submitted a supporting statement that details how the proposed cafe would operate.ldquoIt advises that the proposed cafe would operate within the double-decker bus which is proposed to be sited within the John Muir Way car park for locals and visitors to enjoy.ldquoIt is indicated that the ground floor of the bus would contain a kitchen and one accessible table, with the upper floor of the bus used as a seating area with some  tables and four additional seats.ldquoThe agent indicates that the cafe would operate seasonally from am to pm Tuesday through Sunday from April to September, and from am to pm Wednesday through Sunday from October to March.ldquoThe bus will be positioned on the site at all times and would not be removed when not open for business.The proposals did not attract any comment from the townrsquos community council.One objection from the public focused on the potential of litter and waste from the proposed cafe.However, it was highlighted that matters relating to waste were not ldquomaterial considerations when it came to determining a planning application and would be tackled through other legislation.Planning permission has been given for one year to allow the council to ldquoassess the environmental impact of the development, while a planning condition stating that bins should be provided outside the bus at all times while trading has also been included.

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: community-praised-racing-returns-musselburgh-racecourse
story: Musselburgh Racecourse saw racing resume behind closed doors at two events at the start of the month and held a third event recently.The move involved introducing security measures around the course, which is on Common Good land, to protect the public, racecourse staff and visitingjockeys.The land on which the racecourse operates is a popular walking spot for locals and dog walkers,with neighbouring lagoons.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said the course had received huge support from local residents as it sought to ensure fixtures could be held safely and meet health and safety standards.Ahead of the inaugural meeting, the racecourse put in place a lsquoGreen Zonersquo which ensured admission to the grounds was controlled and monitored to minimise the risk posed by Covid-.Safety barriers were erected at points around the course on Linkfield Road and stewards advised local residents where to access the course without encroaching on the Green Zone.Other measures included all attendees completing a compulsory Covid- education module, an online health questionnaire, providing personal details and photo ID, and on arrival undergoing temperature checks by qualied medical staff.Mr Farnsworth said the protocols had been agreed in advance with East Lothian Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Groupand the British Horseracing Authority in order to meet safety guidelines introduced by the Scottish Government.He said: ldquoWe understand the new procedures may have caused some inconvenience to local residents and we will refine the process when Covid- regulations are relaxed.ldquoWe do appreciate the continued support of the local community in bringing racing back to Musselburgh.ldquoThe purpose of the controlled measures is to ensure the safety of the participants on each race day and the safety of the local community, and we are acting on feedback received from local residents following the first two meetings.ldquoWe have placed additional signage on Linkfield Road to ensure the public who use the links and lagoons for recreation and dog walking are fully aware of the access areas during future race days.ldquoOur aim is to provide as much public access to the grounds surrounding the racecourse as possible, whilst operating a safe sporting event.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. The whole experience was really good. They had some great chats with Mary.ldquoMartin and Roman were so nice and made us feel very at ease.ldquoI was more of a Duran Duran fan but I didnrsquot tell him that!ldquoItrsquos nice that they are recognising kids that have done something that wee bit dferent.ldquoIt was also nice to see what it takes to film a TV show and how it is all done ndash Roman fluffed his lines a couple of times. It was an honour and a privilege to have had the opportunity from ITV.Ahead of watching the show, Karen admitted she was nervous.However, afterwards she described it as ldquoone of the most surreal experiences and said she was really pleased with how the show turned out.She said that both Mary and Abbie also loved filming the show.She added a thanks to Mary for doing her TikTok challenge, which raised more than pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.

title: mum-says-i-literally-begging-people-save-life
story: Trudie Murphy is hoping to fly out to the USA for treatment which could see the tumour removed.She was given the horrible news last week that specialists in Scotland would be unable to remove the cancerous tumour, while chemotherapy was also not an option.Doctors have said that she could receive radiotherapy but it would be as a last resort to extend her le.Now, a close friend, Colin Rillie-Caldwell, has launched an online appeal looking to raise more than pound,, which would be used to cover the cost of treatment.Trudie, who works part-time in Tranentrsquos Asda store, admitted to the Courier she was ldquopessimistic but would love the money to be raised to give her extra time with her children.She said: ldquoI would love to see it happen, to be able to be around for my kids ndash that is my sole driving force.ldquoThis GoFundMe page, I feel embarrassed because I feel like it is begging but I thought: lsquoI am literally begging for people to save my le so that I am here for my kids.rsquoldquoRight now, I just feel like somebody has put a plastic bag over my head and is slowly tightening it and I cannot breathe.ldquoIt is the last thing you think about at night and the first thing you think about in the morning.ldquoYou automatically think you would have it removed and have chemotherapy but to be told that you cannot, that they will not go in and do anythinghellipThe Tranent mum had been referred to hospital for brain and spinal MRIs after it was thought she had MS .However, the scans showed it was worse than first thought, with Trudie, who is mum to Joshand Naomi , who attend Ross High School, Zak , who will be starting at Knox Academy Meadowpark, and eight-year-old Archie, who attends Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, in Tranent, saying she ldquofelt numb after being told she had an inoperable brain tumour.A biopsy and chemotherapy have both been ruled out by experts due to the location of the tumour.She said: ldquoThey donrsquot know how aggressive it is because they cannot do the biopsy.ldquoThey were throwing everything at me ndash there are  types of brain cancer. They donrsquot know how quick it is going to grow.ldquoIrsquove been told I will start to have epileptic fits, I will lose my mobility and even simple things like swallowing I will be unable to do.With options on the NHS limited, Trudie and her husband Dave, who tied the knot  months ago, are looking at the possibility of travelling to America or other countries for treatment.Trudie, who has lived in Tranent for about eight years after previously living in Musselburgh, where she attended the townrsquos secondary school, said a hospital in America could use a needle ldquoas thin as a hair to take a biopsy, while the possibility of operating on the tumour had not been ruled out.Unfortunately, that would mean raising thousands of pounds to cover expensive medical bills.Friends and family rallied round for the online appeal, with more than pound, already raised.Trudie, , encouraged people to get in touch with raffle prizes for a future fundraiser and said: ldquoPeople can surprise you.ldquoIt is not always the people you are closest to that reach out but people I have not spoken to for a while that reach out to you."There are strangers I have never met that are donating money to somebody that they donrsquot know, especially just now because of lockdown.ldquoEverybody has been affected by this financially one way or another and I certainly did not expect to get over pound,.Dave, who works as a residential childcare worker in Ormiston, described the news as ldquodevastating.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to put it into words."She is so young, has so much to give and has so much to look forward to for this to potentially take her away, knowing potentially that something can be done ndash there are no words.To support Trudie, go to gofundme f treatment-for-trudie

title: plans-car-park-elcho-green-shelved
story: Councillors and council officials have this week been inundated with angry comments from disbelieving residents, protesting against cherished recreational area Elcho Green, at North Berwickrsquos West Bay, being utilised for an -space long-stay car park.The local authority said in a statement last Tuesday that, as part of ious measures inNorth Berwick to provide extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-, including widening pavements at the east end of High Street, it would be ldquoconverting part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.It stated that ldquofollowing a meeting with local traders, North Berwick CommunityCouncil and North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, agreement has been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town ndash but both the community council and area partnership told the Courier they had not given backing to the Elcho Green changes.The councilrsquos own timetable had Elcho Green car park opening last Friday .An online petition, West Bay not Parking Bay, to ldquoprotect stunning and iconic West Bay in North Berwick, was launched by resident Sarah Russell and had attracted more than , signatures in less than a week.It said: ldquoEast Lothian Council have announced plans to turn Elcho Green into a longstay car park.ldquoWhilst the council state that this is a temporary measure to comply with their Covid Spaces for People initiative, it is greatly feared that this will, in fact, lead to a permanent car park in the most iconic seafront location in East Lothian."North Berwick residents and visitors alike will be robbed of the very essence of this beautul recreational space that personies this famous conservation area seafront.ldquoTemporary or otherwise, Elcho Green is not the correct location for any car parking and we would urge you to help us stop this environmental catastrophe.Among those supporting the campaign was world-famous golfer and North Berwick resident Catriona Matthew, captain of Europersquos winning Solheim Cup team.The Courier has been swamped with letters and emails against the plans .The scheme was described as ldquoindefensible and ldquoundemocratic vandalism by some residents, while many asked why there had not been specic consultation on the plan and highlighted that the land had been gted to the town by the late Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple for recreational use in .On Monday, East Lothian Council released a statement that it was placing the ldquoElcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult.It is the second time in a month that the councilrsquos plans to transform town centres have hit the buffers.Earlier in July, proposals to suspend parking in town centres were put ldquoon hold after traders and residents in Haddington reacted with anger as cones and parking suspension signs were put up overnight, sparking widespread concern.In Mondayrsquos statement, Councillor Norman Hampshire , environment spokesperson, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has successfully implemented a number of physical distancing measures on North Berwick High Street to support the need for safe access to the town centre and economic recovery.ldquoA further support for Spaces for People was a proposal to utilise a small part of Elcho Green in North Berwick as a temporary car park.ldquoThe benefit of this would have been a reduction in the number of vehicles circling and queuing for parking spaces, enhanced safety for pedestrians and cyclists within the town centre, and improved air quality.ldquoEast Lothian Council is a listening authority and we are aware of the ious perspectives being raised within the North Berwick community.ldquoAs such, we intend to place the Elcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult."This delay will also enable us to monitor the impact of increased traffic as a result of visitors and to assess the effectiveness of measures introduced.Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, said that recent u-turns were down to a ldquolack of political leadership within the Labour administration.He said he received more than  emails objecting to the Elcho Green plans.He called for a report on the Spaces for People plans, and in particular parking proposals in North Berwick, to be put before a meeting of elected council group leaders in two weeksrsquo time for approval.Under emergency Covid- procedures, normal council business is currently suspended and decisions are taken at monthly meetings of the group leaders and council chief executive.He said: ldquoThe decision must be approved by councillors at the leadersrsquo group meeting and it should be open and transparent and open to the press.Mr Hampshire accused Mr Currie of ldquoplaying politics in ldquoan emergency situation.ldquoWe have allowed him to take part in the meetings with officers at every point during the discussions, said Mr Hampshire.ldquoI have got to say the Conservative Group have been fully behind what we are doing."For the SNP to try to play politics in a situation where their own Government is instructing local authorities to create spaces in town centres is unbelievable.Conservative councillor Craig Hoy called on the administration to ldquotake notice of the recent problems caused by parking proposals.He said the Scottish Government had failed to give councils enough time to push through emergency Covid measures in town centres.Councillor Hoy said: "Scottish Councils are operating under huge pressure with limited resources, but that does not remove the need for them to consult fully and communicate clearly on big issues which impact our communities."I hope East Lothian Council and the Labour administration will take notice of the recent problems in North Berwick and fully engage with stakeholders."Hilary Smith, chair of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, stressed that the area partnership had not attended any meeting regarding Covid- plans for the town or given its approval to the plans.North Berwick Community Council said it had not discussed Elcho Green prior to its meeting on Tuesday.East Lothian Council received pound.million from Scottish Government funding for Spaces for People projects to make social distancing easier in town centres and encourage people toto them safely.The council launched a consultation in May, asking people for their county-wide views.It attracted , contributions and more than  comments, including more than  from the North Berwick area.But North Berwick residents have not been asked their specic views on Elcho Green car parking.The council said it had given consideration to parking availability at a number of sites in North Berwick.In response to questions from the Courier, the council said: ldquoThe high school and sports centre are both due to re-open in coming weeks so were unsuitable to use.ldquoAn area of Elcho Green is considered suitable to take traffic arriving from the west to park for people visiting the town to intercept the flow of traffic and stop vehicles circulating through the town unnecessarily searching for parking spaces and generating additional traffic pollution.ldquoIt also seemed reasonable considering the area of land is used annually for Fringe by the Sea events."A maximum of  places had been identied for use as a potential temporary car park which is not part of the Spaces for People grant but provided as part of the programme.

title: world-famous-singer-pops-east-lothian-cafe
story: Sam visited JoLi, based in The Old Reading Rooms on Longniddryrsquos Main Street.Sam is said to have bought a coffee and some gts, with those at the cafe saying that the Grammy Award-winner stopped off on their travels to North Berwick.Staff at JoLi were ldquoa little bit starstruck when the singer popped by, saying the visit was ldquosomething you do not expect.They described the singer as a ldquolovely guy.A post sharing the news of the visit on social media has attracted a lot of attention from starstruck fans, with one fellow diner saying that she was in having lunch at the time and did not recognise the star.Sam, , is a British singer-songwriter who emerged onto the music scene in .Since then the musician, who delayed the release of their third album, has had several number one and top  hits in both the UK and US, and in  released Writingrsquos on the Wall, the theme song for the James Bond film Spectre.As well as Grammy Awards, Sam has won Brit Awards, Billboard Music Awards, American Music Awards, a Golden Globe and an Academy Award.It is believed Sam is on holiday in East Lothian with his family.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-reopens-doors-today
story: The coronavirus pandemic forced the venue to close in mid-March but now preparations have been made and put in place for its reopening.The Seabird Centre, which is an independent charity, will open Thursday-Sunday, am-pm, in what it describes as a ldquohugely positive step.It will then close Monday-Wednesday to allow staff to review the visitor experience over the temporary opening time and make improvements where needed.Staff at the centre are ldquoreally excited to welcome people back and hope to be back to a daily am-pm opening from next Thursday .Several new processes are in place to help manage numbers and ensure everyone can visit safely, including a new booking system.The number of people allowed in at any one time will be signicantly reduced to about  per cent of normal capacity to allow for physical distancing.Because of this reduction, the Seabird Centre will only be able to earn a fraction of its usual income, meaning its future in the months ahead ldquoremains challenging.Having to suddenly close its doors in March due to Covid- had a ldquodevastating effect on the Seabird Centrersquos finances as it was forced to close at the beginning of the summer tourism season, something it relies on.In May it launched its first-ever urgent public appeal, which saw it aim to raise pound, and save it from permanent closure. This, alongside emergency funding from a number of sources, has allowed the centre to reopen its doors once again and welcome back visitors.Susan Davies, the centrersquos CEO, said: ldquoIt is with great relief that we have been able to navigate a course through this turbulent financial period and are now able to welcome visitors back to our centre.Full details on the new systems, safety procedures and opening dates and times in place can be found at seabird.orgThe Seabird Centrersquos public appeal ends next Friday .To donate, visit justgiving campaign SeabirdSOS

title: coronavirus-scotrail-offers-free-travel-unemployed----even-get-job
story: The coronavirus pandemic has had a huge impact on jobs in Scotland, with figures in May suggesting the number of people claiming unemployment benefit has increased by .% - up about , to ,.The travel firm say that the cost of travelling to an interview can ldquooften be a barrier to ing to work ndash so launched a scheme to fast-track the process.The idea was launched in , but has recently been marketed againby ScotRailas a result of the coronavirus.What can jobseekers get Those eligible can get two freejourneys a month to attend an interview.They can also then get a free ScotRail travel ticket for the first month of theirto work.Jobseekers are also able to take advantage of the Jobcentre Plus Travel Discount Card - a UK Government initiative which allows those who are unemployed and claiming Jobseekerrsquos Allowance or Universal Credit to receive a % discount on selected rail tickets.If youre out of work, were offering two free tickets per month for travel to interviews - as well as a free one month ticket once you secure a job.Am I eligible for the scheme To be eligible for any of these offers, the customer must have been claiming Jobseekers Allowance or Universal Credit for - monthsor - months .How does it work Tickets for travel to interview:For jobseekers to obtain up to two freetickets per month to attend interviews, their local Job Centre issues them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a local station where staff will issue a ticket .One month ticket once employment secured:If the jobseeker secures employment and wishes to apply for a free monthrsquos ticket, their local Job Centre will issue them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a station where staff will issue a ticket .What does ScotRail say ScotRail Alliance Managing Director Alex Hynes said: ldquoFor people out of work, the cost of travelling to an interview can often be a barrier to ing to work.ldquoBy removing that barrier and providing help with the cost, we hope to be able to support people into work and grow Scotlandrsquos economy.ldquoThe support we offer to jobseekers is one of the ScotRail Alliancersquos best kept secrets ndash but I want as many people as possible to know about this opportunity.

title: pubs-busy-open-first-time-months
story: Scottish Government-imposed restrictions to help fight the coronavirus pandemic were relaxed last week, with customers allowed back inside pubs, provided they followed social distancing.Businesses throughout the county were pleased to welcome back thirsty punters, with each reporting a busy weekend.Laura McSweeney, from The Green in Haddington, was pleased with how the weekend had gone.She said people had been ldquorespectful of the restrictions in place and the beer garden was proving popular, with the exception of during poor weather.She added: ldquoIt has been a bit of a mixture to be honest. The usual suspects are coming back but it has been a bit of an unusual time as people are heading back to work.ldquoOverall, we have had a lot more people come in for food and there has been quite a good turnout.Social distancing restrictions are in place at the Court Street pub, with signs reminding people of the restrictions.Meanwhile, staff are wearing visors when serving customers both inside and outside the building.Hand sanitiser is also available, with a strict cleaning schedule in place for the toilets as well.Victoria Fowler, at Musselburghrsquos Sportsman Bar, described trade as ldquoabsolutely brilliant over the weekend.She told the Courier: ldquoIt was much better than we expected.ldquoEverybody seems to be following the rules.ldquoWe were full all the time and having to turn people away.Despite the restrictions, Victoria said the pub, on the townrsquos High Street, had been busy.As well as social distancing, bar stools have been removed, while customers are not allowed to bring their empty glasses back to the bar.Similar to The Green, there is also a rigorous cleaning regime in place as well.William Gordon, manager at The Brig Inn in Tranent, said the beer garden had been full and there had been a good number of visitors.He added that ious restrictions had also been put in place but people seemed to be enjoying themselves.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell, local area commander, had attended Haddingtonrsquos community council, which was held online, last week.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the group, asked what measures police were putting in place ahead of the first weekend of people drinking inside pubs.The senior officer said that licensing officers had liaised with each of the licensed premises across East Lothian ahead of them reopening.He noted that many were simply too small to have a great number of visitors when social distancing was taken into account and officers would be out over the weekend.He said: ldquoRight through the whole of East Lothian, [licensed premises] are really keen to make sure they provide a safe environment for customers.ldquoIf they do that, there will be far less people within their premises.ldquoWe will deal with any complaints in the normal manner.Writing in his Courier column this week, Ch Insp Mitchell was pleased to say that the weekend had gone smoothly.He wrote: ldquoOur licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.

title: virtual-meetings-become-new-normal-council
story: The local authority has signed up to web service Connect Remote at a cost of more than pound, for its first year, to ensure councillors can meet once emergency measures introduced during lockdown are lted.A report to councillors says the service is the latest tool offered by web company Public-i, which already provides web casting facilities to more than  councils, including Midlothian and Edinburgh.It will allow councillors to take part in virtual meetings which are live-streamed and can be accessed by the public as well as being put into an archive to watch back later.Currently some scrutiny meetings have been held via Skype for Business as the council strives to make decisions in public however, a report to councillors said that system was not a ldquolong-term solution for large-scale meetings.It said: ldquoLicences are required for inidual users , administrator s are limited, and it is dficult to manage public lsquoattendancersquo.Instead, the report said, officers had been looking at alternatives as it became clear face to face meetings might not resume for some time.It said: ldquoOfficers have been looking at a iety of options for continuing the democratic process in a way that replicates face-to-face meetings, as well as being accessible by the public.ldquoConnect Remote is a web-based system, so inidual user licences are not required and there is no need to software to be installed on usersrsquo IT equipment."It will allow members and officers to participate in meetings remotely, as well as providing members of the public with access to proceedings, either as they happen or via archived recordings.The report said year one costs for establishing and maintaining the new system were pound,, which would be classedas Covid- related funding and could attract Government support.

title: great-grandmother-celebrates-95th-birthday-95-plus-cards
story: Betty Sneddonwas delighted when relatives paid her a visit on Sunday to wish her many happy s and enjoy a socially distanced party in the garden of her town centre home.She did not want any gts but her family thought it would be a great ideashe received  cards ndash reflecting her age ndash from well-wishers.The number of cards sent has now surpassed the target as relatives and friends, some from abroad, inundated her with birthday messages, much to her surprise and amazement.During the Covid- lockdown, Mrs Sneddon enjoyed spending time in her beloved garden. She was also grateful to a friend who left cakes for her and gave her a wave.Her daughter Mary Blair kept her in touch with family via FaceTime but she was delighted to catch up with them in person on her birthday amid the easing of restrictions.The last surviving member of a family of nine ndash five brothers and four sisters ndash Mrs Sneddon was born in Musselburghrsquos Newbigging, where she first attended school.She was a pupil at Burgh Primary School and went on to secondary school at Fisherrow. She also lived for a time in Kilwinning.On leaving school, she was employed as a housemaid at Inveresk for a short time and also worked at Bruntonrsquos Wire Mill, Musselburgh. She also enjoyed working at LrsquoAperit, a restaurant in Edinburgh.She met her future husband Jimmy Sneddon when he was staying in lodgings in Musselburgh while working as a steel erector at Portobello Power Station. The couple were married at Inveresk Manse and set up home on Moir Avenue.Mrs Sneddon was a soprano and soloist in the famous Musselburgh Fishwives Choir.They sang all over the country and once went to sing for soldiers in recovery after the Second World War at Peel Hospital near Peebles. Her older brother Jim was recovering at the hospital from a severe back injury.A mum of three, grandmother of five and great grandmother of three, she has always filled her le with family and friends.Over the years, she enjoyed attending the Womenrsquos Rural Institute and playing Scrabble with Nancy Herkes, her best friend from school, until they were in their late seventies.A fan of detective programmes and brain-teasers, she said her recipe for a long and happy le was ldquocrosswords, Scrabble, gardening and great grandchildren keep you going ndash not forgetting Morse, Poirot and, of course, good genes.

title: tantallon-dirleton-castles-reopen-within-weeks
story: Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle, near North Berwick, have been closed to visitors by Historic Environment Scotlandduring the coronavirus pandemic.Now, restrictions are easing and Scotlandrsquos biggest operator of visitor attractions has revealed ldquoa phased approach to reopen  per cent of its free-to-access and ticketed properties by mid-September.HESrsquo website lists both Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle among  sites which it hopes to start opening from late August onwards ldquoon a rolling basis.ldquoThese sites will open in consultation with the local communities and reflecting circumstances in each area as much as possible, the website states.Alex Paterson, chief executive of HES, said: ldquoAt the forefront of our planning is the safety of our staff and visitors, whilst being able to reopen for the tourist season by gradually enabling safe access to our properties and facilities in line with Scottish Government guidance.ldquoWersquove been working exceptionally hard to ensure our properties will be accessible and ready to welcome visitors however, itrsquos important that we implement our resumption plans at the right time given the dferent requirements for each site.ldquoThis also includes looking at the ying local and regional requirements throughout the country and we have considered this when setting out our phased approach to welcoming visitors back and supporting Scotlandrsquos tourism and economic recovery.From last Wednesday, HES provided access to more than  unstaffed and key-keeper sites across Scotland, where physical distancing can be readily maintained and where HES can provide free and safe access.When the attractions reopen, visitors, including members, will be required to pre-book tickets online and use contactless payment where possible one-way systems will be implemented in some locations and some areas of sites, such as enclosed spaces, will be closed off.Visitor numbers will also be limited for safety reasons.Mr Paterson added: ldquoWersquore very much looking forward to welcoming visitors back.ldquoThere will of course be some initial changes, including managing visitor numbers at certain sites, as well as restricting access to specic locations, but we can assure visitors of a warm welcome.ldquoWe want to ask our visitors to help create a safe environment by behaving responsibly and following our guidance at properties, and we will be providing further information on our website for visitors to help them prepare for their visit.For more information, visit historicenvironment.scot

title: impressive-turnout-farmers-market-returns-town
story: The market ed to the townrsquos Court Street last Saturday, July , with an impressive turnout.Now, it is getting ready toagain tomorrow .The visitor numbers were revealed by Councillor John McMillan, who represents Haddington on East Lothian Council.The local authorityrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism told members of the townrsquos community council: ldquoAt the farmersrsquo market,  people came in, which is good for the town centre.The popular markets, which sell locally sourced products, had disappeared from the town for four months due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, the organisers worked with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland, among other groups, to see the marketon July .Steps were taken to ensure public safety at the event, with the introduction of a one-way system on Court Street.Visitors to the market entered beside the Corn Exchange before heading towards Brewery Lane and then turning back and leaving through a signed exit.Members of Haddington Rotary Club acted as stewards, while a headcount was also taken.The one-way system will remain in place for Saturdayrsquos market, with a total of  stalls expected to be open.Similarly, hand sanitising stations and stewards will again be on hand to try to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Val Shields, chair of Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, was delighted to say the ing market had proven a great success.She told the Courier: ldquoI think everybody was pleased with it.ldquoIt was a nice relaxed atmosphere.ldquoPeople all did the things they were meant to do and were very patient and kept social distances.ldquoStallholders were quite happy to be back and takings were reasonable overall.ldquoThe weather was nice and everything aligned.ldquoIt was just a good day and everyone ndash customers and stallholders ndash was glad to be back.

title: plans-new-sports-pavilion-north-berwick-get-go-ahead
story: It will be located on land north-east of Wotherspoon Green and have an adjacent car park with  spaces, two of which will be for electric vehicles, with a charger point, and three for disabled users.Final plans for the car park area changed slightly from initial designs, including the entrance to the car park being moved and a path that led to the building removed.The interior of the single-storey building has not changed and will contain two changing rooms, each with a separate shower and toilet, two toilets, a plant room, storage cupboard, clubroom and accessible toilet.There will also be two bike racks.The application received six objections, all of which related to loss of privacy, loss of daylight, concerns relating to the use of floodlights, the buildingrsquos visual appearance, an increase in road traffic and pedestrians, and increase in noise at anti-social hours.The sports pavilion, which could be named after the late Pilmar Smith ndash a North Berwick legend who was former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian Football Club and former chairman of Lothian Buses ndash will not have floodlights.A council planning officerrsquos report said: ldquoThe sports pavilion is directly related to the future provision of the sports pitch to the south and would serve as a recreational facility for North Berwick and the existing and future residents of the wider Mains Farm development site.It is not known when work will begin on the building due to the current coronavirus restrictions.

title: community-resilience-groups-cockenzie-port-seton-dunbar-gullane-haddington-humbie-musselburgh-north-berwick-prestonpans-tranent-elphinstone-work-hard
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at nine of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonWHILE work goes on to wind down the resilience effort and prepare the community in Cockenzie and Port Seton for le after lockdown, volunteers have continued to provide assistance and receive donations.The local resilience effort has been led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, which has this week continued to pay tribute to its volunteers on social media.The craft club at Chalmers Memorial Church has been making masks and donated some to the resilience team.Meanwhile, local people, including those in Longniddry, can visit the pantry at Port Seton Centre for food and other items.Delivery is also available by phoning the centre on  .Throughout lockdown, East Lothian Council staff at the centre have been making meals and, alongside resilience volunteers, delivering them to residents.Thanks was also given from Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership to Scotmid for the donation of deodorant and body wash it gave to the centre when it went to pick up toiletries for the pantry.The resilience effort will wind down either at the end of the month or when children go back to school in August.Contact detailsTo contact the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, call  .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar are getting ready to hand over the reins to East Lothian Council.Volunteers from throughout the town and neighbouring West Barns have been working to support vulnerable members of the two communities.The community resilience team will take a step back at the end of the month.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, said a lot of volunteers were already stepping away due to work commitments or to go on holiday.He said: ldquoIrsquove found it to be in some ways quite rewarding because it was very gratying to see what a positive response we had from the local community and how people stepped forward as volunteers."This started in mid-March when we set up those teams, we have come a long way now. People are getting fatigued and quite glad to be stepping down and do less.The community was split into nine clusters, with each assigned a lead volunteer.George told the Courier that the busiest cluster would receive about  calls a week when restrictions were at their peak.People would collect prescriptions and shopping, as well as take dogs for a walk.Hot meals were also delivered to those in need while volunteers worked with Dunbarrsquos foodbank.Electronic devices were also blanked and given a new lease of le with students in the town who were studying from home with schools closed.However, as restrictions have eased, George said the number of calls had ldquodropped right off.Volunteers have agreed to be on hand in case of a second spike and will be ready to ramp up their efforts should the need arise.Contact detailsTo contact the Dunbar resilience team, email Dunbar.covid@gmailGullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneCHEQUES totalling more than pound, have been handed over to five good causes. Members of Gullane Resilience Team thanked the community for donating goods and money throughout lockdown.The money was added to cash raised through the sales of bread flour and face coverings before a cheque presentation was made.Gullane Village Hall received pound,, with a further pound going to Muirfield Riding Therapy and pound to Brain Tumour Research.East Lothian Foodbank received pound, with pound going to the Gullane Scrubbers.Contact detailsContact the team for help on   or by emailing gullanerteam@gmailHaddingtonHaddingtonTHE head of Haddingtonrsquos community resilience team has described the efforts of volunteers as ldquofantastic.A squad of members of the public, giving up their own time, has been on standby in the town since the middle of March in a bid to help anyone affected by the coronavirus.As lockdown restrictions are eased, the community resilience team is set to take a step back at the end of the month.Chris McEwan, who has been at the heart of the Haddington team, told the Courier that the number of calls in recent weeks had dried up as people slowly got back to normality.He said: ldquoIn the beginning, it was utterly stressful because we did not have anything in place that would even remotely deal with this."We had to build a resilience team up of volunteers."Everything  we had beforehand was round about community council members and a few other people like the events group and Christmas lights team."We could call upon each other to help out and in the past that has been spreading some grit or helping out here or there but nothing like this whatsoever.Volunteers have been on hand to offer a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions, as well as the delivery of hot meals to people through Our Community Kitchen.Copies of the Courier have also been delivered to people, while volunteers have called vulnerable people to check in with them.Earlier in lockdown, Chris made face shields, using a D printer, for people in the healthcare sector.Recently, more shields have been produced for people as businesses begin to reopen.Chris added that community resilience groups from across East Lothian had been coming together to share their Covid- experiences.He felt that had been a real benefit and hoped that would be used in futurethe community resilience teams ever had to tackle something similar.He said: ldquoTowards the end, as it is calming down, I have been really impressed with what we have done as volunteers."It has been really fantastic and I am hoping that goodwill goes on.Contact detailsAnyone needing assistance can call   between am and pm.Further information is available from haddingtoncc.org.ukHumbie.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.HumbieVOLUNTEERS will continue to be on hand to offer assistance to people in Humbie.Community resilience teams across East Lothian are getting ready to wind up at the end of the month as lockdown restrictions continue to ease.Al Beck, treasurer of Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and Bolton Community Council, stressed they would continue to be available to people.Humbie volunteers have also been working alongside neighbouring Fala to help any members of the community who require assistance.Al said: ldquoLike many of the small groups, there has not been a huge demand."We have had more volunteers than we require to provide a service but we have been happy to be there."Everybody has been happy to be involved and be availablerequired.He added a lot of neighbours were looking after each other rather than contacting the resilience team but stressed they were there to offer assistance.Contact detailsContact Margo Hodge from the resilience team on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghRESILIENT Musselburgh is continuing to move into ldquocommunity recovery as the Covid- lockdown eases.Up to July , the army of volunteers delivered , lunches to preschool children,  emergency food packs, , meals from catering company Hickory, , soup and sandwich meals, four utility top-ups,  hearing aid batteries,  prescriptions, seven supplies of books, three lsquoclick and collectrsquo orders,  garden tools,  requests for information, and  adult and  children activity packs.The resilience efforts in the Musselburgh area, which includes Wallyford and Whitecraig, are led by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThe need for support has been decreasing slowly over the last few weeks."Hopefully we will see a continued decrease over the next few weeks as the phasedout of lockdown moves forward."This will enable our voluntary resources and East Lothian Council colleagues to focus on moving forward into community recovery.Contact detailsGet in touch with Resilient Musselburgh on  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickTHE North Berwick Resilience Group sewing team celebrated the milestone of making , face masks with the unveiling of a giant face covering.Khlayre Cairney said she was very proud of the achievement.She said: ldquoWe have a great sewing team who have done a wonderful job.The face coverings are being given out free on Friday mornings at North Berwick Community Centre, am-noon.Meanwhile, North Berwick Resilience Group team is about to enter its final full week before closing down next Friday .North Berwick community councillor Sue Northrop, who holds responsibility for the community council emergency plan, said the team had been busy working with East Lothian Council to ensure that people who needed access to council and care services were properly supported.Over the weekend, the team held the last of three community workshops on Covid- to get the wider community views and experiences of le in North Berwick with Covid.Sue said: ldquoThis will inform the teamrsquos final report and the future community emergency resilience plan for North Berwick."The team has done a fantastic job, complementing the support given by families, friends, and the wider community."We have lots of people to say thank you to for their help and support over the past four and a bit months."Our priority is to make sure that essential support is now provided by council services and that people know who to contact when they need help."We hope there wonrsquot be a spike or second wave, but we will be working with the whole community to look at how we work together in future emergences.Contact detailsFor help with shopping or prescriptions, go to www.nbresilience or phone  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansWORK continues in Prestonpans to keep supporting those in need as lockdown restrictions are relaxed.Brian Weddell, Prestonpans Community Council chairman, said despite the moves to ease some of the restrictions, the community resilience team continued to provide vital services.He said: ldquoMuch of the media focus over the past week has been on the re-opening of pubs and restaurants and with it the added concern that more people may be exposed to Covid- as a consequence."Clearly no one wants to see a negative outcome with a second wave of coronavirus cases causing ato stricter lockdown measures."Whilst the UK and Scottish Governments have relaxed lockdown rules, there has been no relaxation of the work of our willing team of volunteers who continue to help deliver shopping, collect prescriptions and are doing dog walks."When you consider that some of our volunteers are still working, their support and commitment is really admirable."A special mention needs to go to Prestonpans acting SPoC Allan Sneddon, who has continued to work during the crisis and has not only headed our resilience effort ndash Allan led from the front delivering meals, leaflets, shopping for elderly residents and doing the occasional dog walk."A huge amount of work is still going on at the Pennypit with a lot of people still accessing their pantry , which really goes to show the need for this."The Pennypit Trust are currentlylooking at plans for the future, with a view to keeping the pantry running and the possibility of extending current services to meet the nutritional needs of the elderly and vulnerable in the community.The Pennypit has also been organising activities for youngsters during the holidays to keep them active and exercising.Anyone who needs support from the Pennypit Trust should contact Lorna on   or email lornabellany@gmail.Jane Russellrsquos Sunday chicken dinners continue to provide fresh meals every weekend to more than  households across East Lothian and meals can be ordered on the grouprsquos Facebook page or on  .The community team gave a special mention this week to Jane Shepherd, Tesco Musselburghrsquos Community Food Champion, who assembled  crates of food provisions over the last week, and Scotmid which has provided daily food supplies throughout the past four months.Contact detailsContact the resilience team on   or at prestonpansresilience@gmailTranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT Emergency Response Team will stand down next Fridayand released its plan for what people can dothey still need help or still wish to volunteer.Volunteers will, after this date, no longer be needed to provide support in the community such as assisting with shopping, prescriptions, dog walking and checking on vulnerable people, services they have provided continuously since March.It also means these services will no longer be available as part of the community resilience initiative.The teamrsquos Facebook Messenger service and emergency telephone number will also no longer be available at the end of the month.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone has been led by the local community council and overseen by member, and single point of contact, Mike Falconer.Mike has continuously provided updates to the volunteers on Facebook group lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Mike said: ldquoI am sure that many of those volunteers will continue to help out but simply as good neighbours."If you or someone you know is having dficulty and requires help after that date, we will be publishing a list of services, contact details and information on [the Facebook] page, on the Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council Facebook page and on our noticeboard in the car park at Winton Place Lindores Drive."If you are interested in volunteering here or where in East Lothian, check out Volunteer East Lothian ."Take care, stay safe and hopefully we wonrsquot need to resume operations!"Thanks to all of the wonderful volunteers, the rest of the team and the generous donations of time, money and effort which you, the community, have given over the last few months. You have all been great!Meanwhile, Mike thanked volunteer Susan Coyle, who made about  fabric masks. Resilience volunteers distributed these masks last week.Mike said: ldquoSusan has probably been the busiest of our volunteers over the last few months ndash collecting shopping and prescriptions and checking on neighbours. Well done, you are a star!Susan was presented with a bouquet of flowers from David Forrest, chair of Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, as a token of thanks.Contact detailsContact the resilience team on   or at tranentemergencyresponse@gmailOther resilience groups contact detailsAberladyIan Malcolm  Sam Robertson  www.facebook AberladyResilience-BoltonShena Jamieson   orshenajamieson@aolDirletonwww.dirletonresilience.orgEast SaltounBuffy Neilson   orbuffyneilson@yahooGfordJo Allen  chairgfordcc@gmailAdam White  adamjswhite@outlookWendy Ferguson  wendyferguson.wf@gmailThe Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell  anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukLongniddrySheila Jamieson  Macmerry  Gladsmuir communityresilienceteam@gmailOrmiston OrmistonRCteam@hotmailWest SaltounDerek Smith  coruisk@gmail

title: bid-drive-thru-coffee-shop-eyesore-service-area
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission to build a coffee shop with drive-thru and create additional car parking.There would also be a new dedicated entrance to serve the adjacent Travelodge hotel.More than  jobs would be created as a result of the development.The hotel used to share an entrance with the now vacant Burger King and Little Chef restaurants, which closed several years ago.The site is located close to Old Craighall Roundabout which connects the A Edinburgh City Bypass to the A.North of the site is the B that connects to Monktonhall and then Musselburgh beyond, with the town centre .km from the service area.Tony Thomas, director of East Linton-based APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoThe plan is to demolish part of the original building complex that previously housed Burger King and Little Chef, and create a more dedicated and convenient car park for the Travelodge.ldquoOn the western part of the site we are proposing a drive-thru coffee outlet. Apart from that, the site will be landscaped and upgraded.He said that the current petrol station there, also owned by the Motor Fuel Company, would remain in use.Mr Thomas could not yet say which company would run the drive-thru coffee shop however, an image of the proposed outlet shows a logo for Starbucks.He said it was hoped the work would be completed within a yearplanning consent was granted.A landscape design report, submitted with the planning application, said the ldquoenhanced car park arrangement would provide nine accessible parking bays close to the building entrances and five electric car charging points.It added: ldquoWith the proposed coffee shop there is an opportunity to provide two areas of external seating ndash these have been carefully sited to maximise a south-facing aspect so that visitors can make the most of sunshine.ldquoBoth of these seating areas have plant beds located close by.ldquoThese beds will help to create a sense of enclosure."These plant beds will be planted with a iety of trees, shrubs and hardy perennial plants that will provide seasonal interest.ldquoThe plants will also help to screen any queuing cars into the drive-thru.ldquoTo the front of the retained Travelodge building, we have proposed another plant bed, planted with native trees ndash birch and rowan ndash and robust groundcover.ldquoElsewhere in the new car park, we have looked to punctuate the space with street trees these trees will help to provide vertical structure to the space.ldquoThe proposals look to retain the dense group of semi-mature trees to the west of the site.ldquoTo the north of the site there is a row of sycamore trees that will also be retained.ldquoWith the demolition of the building, there will be a gap in these trees and it is proposed that an additional four sycamore trees are planted to complete the row.ldquoThese trees will work as a buffer between the new car park and the road.ldquoTo make way for the development we are proposing to remove five small trees within the car park that have failed to establish.Other tree planting will take place around the site.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, welcomed the plan, saying: ldquoIt is an eyesore at the moment and something needed to be done for a while ndash as long as the landscaping fits in with the rest of the area.Ward councillor Stuart Currie, who is not a member of the councilrsquos planning committee, added: ldquoA big part of the site has been lying empty for some time and has become a real eyesore.ldquoThe entire site is already set up as a drive-thru facility alongside the hotel so, as long as itrsquos contained within the current boundary [Irsquom happy to support it].ldquoIt will create jobs and be brought back into full use from a boarded-up building.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, said: ldquoThere seems merit in it."Itrsquos a gap site and the facilities would enhance the area.ldquoAs long as it abides by any criteria set by council, the work and project seem welcome.

title: nurses-covid-19-efforts-win-hotel-stay-anywhere-world
story: Alison Williams, a research nurse at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, was nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel of North Berwick.The -year-old Edinburgh resident, who visited North Berwick on holidays as a child, has been branded a ldquosuperhero after raising more than pound, in her campaign to create lsquoRainbow Boxesrsquo for patients.The campaign started after Alison witnessed first-hand that several patients had few personal items as family members were unable to visit them, so did not have basic items such as pyjamas and toiletries.She said: ldquoA lot of people were being admitted in emergency situations so they didnrsquot have and were missing essential items, from nightwear to phone chargers.She added that other initiatives aimed to help nurses, whereas this specically helped patients.The mum of two, who studied at Napier University and qualied in , then came up with the idea to get these items to the patients and launched a campaign on a local Facebook group, Edinburgh Gossip Girls, with the original aim of raising pound to create the boxes.To date the total stands at more than pound,, with a further pound, donated from RBS, bringing the total raised to more than pound,.Alison said: ldquoThe pound target was smashed in a few minutes.She now has a small team of people supporting her.She added: ldquoWe have enough money to last until October but hopefully things will be back to normal [by then] and people can come in on visits and the need wonrsquot be as great.Boxes are delivered to all  wards in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, as well as nearby hospices and the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.Her campaign, alongside her job as a nurse and working during the current coronavirus crisis, led to her being nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel.The competition was featured in Travel Weekly, a travel industry trade magazine, and run by travel company Stuba, in recognition of the hard work of local heroes who have emerged during the pandemic.People were in with a chance of winning a pound hotel voucher. Alison was one of  national winners.Isobel McCardie, who runs Rock My World Travel alongside her husband Mark, nominated Alison.Isobel, who lives in North Berwick, said: ldquoWhen I saw what Alison was doing, it instantly resonated with me.ldquoNot only was she on the frontline fighting Covid-, but her compassion for the patients inspired her to go further.ldquoAs soon as I saw the competition, I instantly thought of Alison. She has been completely selfless in this entire task and is working tirelessly, I canrsquot think of anyone who deserves a break more.On the nomination, Alison said: ldquoI only knew about it when she phoned me and told me Irsquod won. Itrsquos really nice that someone who doesnrsquot know me nominated me. Itrsquos amazing and flattering.Alison plans to take her colleague Rachel, who has been working tirelessly to help Alison with her campaign.When askedshe had decided where to go, Alison said: ldquoIrsquom not wanting to go too far. Irsquoll possibly go somewhere in Scotland.

title: alcohol-confiscated-youths-sent-back-midlothian
story: As the Covid- restrictions are slowly eased, policing and our response is ing to a more recognised model.This week we have reinstated our appointments system where we can again come to you at a convenient time that fits into your day, deal with your enquiry over the phone or attend immediately where required.Officers are slowly ing to their normal working locations with new social distancing measures implemented and calls we are attending are more like what I would expect at this time of year.Face masks, particularly on public transport and in shops, have been a hot topic and the current guidance is that they must be worn.Police officers in the exercise of their duty are exempt from this however, I have instructed that unless it is an emergency, my officers will wear face masks in shops and on transport.In my last few columns, I have commented on a rise in large groups of youths congregating and in some instances causing anti-social behaviour.Over the past few weeks I have had additional patrols and resources allocated to this and we have worked closely with East Lothian Council Safer Community Team.What we have found is that groups of youths have been coming down from Midlothian and engaging in disorder with some youths from East Lothian.At the weekend, my officers dealt with a large gathering of youths who were dispersed and got buses back up to Midlothian.Some youths were charged, alcohol was confiscated and others will receive a letter home addressed to their parents through our Parental Advisory Lettersystem.This early action prevented disorder occurring later in the day and we will continue to do this over the coming weeks.Our road and speed checks across the hotspot and coastal areas continue and we have contributed signicantly to the national summer drug drink driving campaign.Our licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.The beaches and beauty spots continue to bring people from all over Scotland and, now with the English school holidays started, further afield.Last weekend I witnessed first-hand the fantastic work done by East Lothian Council employees to keep the areas safe and clean in very challenging circumstances.The next stage of lockdown is still a while away and I ask that you all continue to follow the current guidelines set to keep yourself and others safe.If you are getting a holiday, I hope it is a pleasant one and that you get good weather to enjoy it.

title: wildlife-diary-studying-kingfisher
story: Although Zan has always had an interest in photography, it was after moving to Scotland that she discovered a passion for wildle and now spends every spare moment pursuing that endeavour.This has led her to volunteering for multiple wildle charities, as well as studying for an MSc in Wildle, Biology and Conservation alongside her photography. In this monthly column, she shares her wildle diary ndash and pictures!DURING lockdown, I was trying to make the most of my free time ndash going on daily walks, working on my website, editing photos from before lockdown, designing my first book and completing A LOT of jigsaws .After the lockdown restrictions started to ease, I was able to spend even more time outdoors than I would normally do. I dedicated June to visiting dferent local sites to watch the kingfisher ndash which you may remember from my previous article ndash a family of wrens and the brown hares.One evening, as I was uploading my photographs on to social media and searching through the pages, I came across a few images of a bird that every birder wanted to see since its influx to the UK was published. It was a rosy starling!The beautul rosy starlinglooks nothing like the starlings we know. It strongly resembles a magpiewith a much shorter tail.This species is unmistakable in its adult plumage.
